text: Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #57. Draught pint (in a Surly glass) at Café 28 (RIP) in Minneapolis, August 2008. Translucent, slightly cloudy amber-brown with a lasting bit of off-white fine-bubbled foam...fruity, resinous, somewhat earthy aroma, touches of dried hops...dry and earthy in the body, lightly peppery, some sweeter, juicier touches show up with time though it remains just a touch too dry for me...notes say "toasted bread but no marmalade" what the hell? anyway, strong tingly carbonation is a bit strong also...this was served too cold and improved quite a bit over a long tasting with some warmth; I look forward to trying it again now that I can get the commoner Surlys pretty easily.
Pours hazy yellow with a huge rocky white head. Nose is yeasty and spicy. Taste is toasty malt, spicy and floral hops, black pepper. Finishes dry and bitter. Definitely an a-typical bitter.
Pale yellow but a bit hazy pour. Thin white head. Citrus, pineapple, almost candied citrus on the nose. Flavor is orangey/grapefruit. A bit odd. Not what I was expecting.
Light opaque dark yellow, fluffy white foam head. Hoppy aroma and strong bitter taste. Some citrus ntes. Like this. (Velp, 201512)
16oz can to tulip. Pours clear straw/gold, white sticky head. Aroma of pine, grapefruit and peppercorn. Taste is the same. As advertised...less malt backbone, but great beer.

Can. Hazy, light orange body with an inch plus of white head. Aromas of citrus, earthy hops, pine, alcohol. Bitter indeed. Resinous, earthy hops. Light, even thin, bodied with aggressive bitterness, peaking mid to late palate. Not the easy drinking, session beer renowned in England.

16oz can. Pale yellow pour with a big soapy head of huge bubbles. The head diminishes like the frothy on a milkshake; around the edges first and leaves a lumpy residue. Bitter hop aroma that is very attractive. Flavors are bright, clean, refreshing bitterness. Delicious. I love the low alcohol content. Easy to drink. Well deserved reputation.

Can at home, pours a hazy yellow with thick head and average retention. Leaves a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma is citrusy hops, lightly fruity. Taste is orange, light tropical fruit, clean, but extremely bitter. Pretty enjoyable. Lots of flavor from a low ABV beer.
Yet another disappointment from Surly. The flavor actually isnt awful - kind of a sour pineapple - but aftertaste is wretchedly bitter.
Canned, from Art, golden color with some bubbly foam, aroma of lemon fruit stripe gum and melon, flavor is more fruity citrus, light hop finish

Poured from a can. Hazy yellow to golden orange with a thin white head that doesnt last long. Has a weird dry finish that doesnt get pulled away. Faint Citrus aromas and flavor kinda. This one is just missing something on every category for me. Maybe a bad can?
On tap for a pre GTMW party, pours a hazy yellow with a thin head, the aroma is hoppier than I was expecting, nice citrus touch mixed in with some sweetness, very light and easy drinking.
Draft. Murky yellow orange color. Aroma of citrus. Taste is bitter grapefruit. Bitter???
Can pour at home, thanks Andrew for this one, lemon juice color pour, slight bitter aroma with a citrus bitter taste.

pours a hazy lemon gold with a medium frothy lacy white head. Aroma is pine and citrus hoppy. creamy mouth feel. moderately bitter taste, slight citrus but with some definite malt presence. quite a bitter linger that coats the palate on the finish. I like it!

16 oz can poured. Pours a bright cloudy yellow color with a fizzy head. Tropical fruit, and hop heavy forward aroma. Pretty light in overall flavor content, but extremely refreshing. Subtle orange and peach flavor, and finishes on a bitter hop note. Very nice, unique beer to try. Good stuff.

On tap. Pours a cloudy straw gold with a white head and lacing. It has a nice aroma of grass, floral hops, some citrus with a flavor of spicy, floral, and herbal notes up front and a spicy, light finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cloudy light orange with a white head. Clean citrus on the nose, amazing for a 4% bitter. Taste is clean and citrusy with a little dry malt on the back end.

Pours somewhat hazy apricot with a fairly thick eggshell head. Malty aroma has a strong hoppy hay overtone. Flavor has malty, hay, and subtle lemonade notes, definitely refreshing. Texture is, well, not much; still, it goes down well. Dont surly, be bitter.

[Can] Bright golden pour with a slight haze to it. Aromas of grassy hops, bready malts and some caramel. Clean and crisp hop notes are the main feature in the taste. Some perfume, grass, sweet fruits and mineral notes as well. Light in body, but still quite flavorful.
Can to shaker. Nice clean crisp and citrusy hop profile. Sessionable deliciousness.
16oz can pours a hazy pale brown color without much head. Nice ESB style hop profile. Clean and refreshing.
Can. Color is hazy orange with solid white head. Big hop aroma slight citrus rind. Taste is slight bitter very light.

Id probably call this an APA rather than a bitter but I dont feel like arguing so whatever. This is a slightly cloudy orange beer w/ a head of white, fine bubbles. It smells really nice and fruity, definite peach and tangerine notes. It is a touch on the bland side when you taste it though, no real malt character comes through and its just a firm bit of bitterness in the finish. I think this might work OK as a light, refreshing beer but the texture is a bit full bodied for that. It drinks pretty easily w/ its mild carbonation but feels a bit too oily on the tongue for something that doesnt have much depth of flavor. I dont mind this stuff but I dont see myself buying it again.

A crisp hoppy and lightly sweet beer. Light citrus aroma and taste (grapefruit, apricot, etc) finishes bitter, clean, and light. Refreshing and drinkable. Could be confused with a session ipa but is slightly different. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

good stuff, especially at only 4%?! started out boring, just because ive been drinking lots of BIG beers lately, and big this is not. but its subtle floral aroma mixes well with the bittering hops and sweet fruity malt. well balanced too. i could have lots of these. one of my new favorite bitters"
Tap, amber pour, off white head, nose is caramel, taste is caramel, smooth, easy drinking beer.

Draft at the brewery! This has a pretty standard visual for a Bitter, amber and a bit of thin head. In a blind taste, Id call this a even-keeled American pale ale. Theres a firm malty backbone, followed by a little fruit/woody twist. (#5650, 8/28/2014)
On tap at bait shop with hakes dr.. hazy orange copper pour.. diffrent taste and aroma .. Strange ...kinda dig it tho..
Tallboy. Pours a hazy rich golden color with a thin white head. Floral hop aromas. Taste is mineral water,earthy hops and pale malt. Quite good. Nice dry, bitter finish borders an APA.
user_location: Menasha Red Light District, Wisconsin, USA

text: 16 oz can purchased from Binnys. Pours a clear dark amber orange with many particulates floating in the glass creating a cloudy appearance. The thick white head settled down to a thin edge head and a tiny wisp atop the meniscus. Aroma is mild with dry hopped complexity - light orange citrus predominantly. Flavor is same with mild hops and light citrus. Light to medium bodied, bright carbonation and lingering ale yeast finish.
Draft at Bricks. Pours somewhat cloudy orange-amber with no head or lacing. Very mild hops in the nose. Grassy bitterness in the taste. Buttery mouthfeel. Lots of flavor for 4.1%.

Very nice floral hop aroma to start, pours a clear light orangish-amber with a thin white head. Fruity sweetness starts off the beer, changing to a lingering bitter finish. Very light bodied and easy drinking. A solid example of the style.
Poured a light golden color. Light sweet aroma. Interesting taste. It has this buttery characteristic that reminds me of Abrasive. Also has a gritty maltyness to it. Its decent.

light beige head leaves no lacing. orangeblonde colour. aroma of orangeblossoms and bergamot. taste like aroma, quite crisp and drinkable with a fair bitter aftertaste. rather thin body, medium carbonation.  can 50 cl

(Tasting sessions with Frank). Une canette qui porte la date suivante: 05/12/14. Un liquide ambré et embrouillé sur lequel flotte une mousse généreuse de son temps. Le nez est plein de houblons en feuilles, en fleurs et en fruits. La base maltée procure une certaine douceur qui naffecte pas vraiment la présence houblonnée. En bouche, cest beaucoup moins évident ou réussi. Les houblons sont nettement moins vigoureux et prennent leau. Les céréales sont ainsi lavées. En bouche, le liquide mapparaît assez mince et bien pétillant. La finale montre des notes sèches qui sestompent avec rapidité.

Aroma is fruit, citrus, tropical fruit and a hint of earthy malts. The flavor is tropical fruit, citrus, fruit, biscuit malts, fruit and a mildly bitter/tart finish. Leans toward ESB but definitely had APA qualities from the hops.
Pours a slightly hazy golden with white head. Pine, citrus and light fruits, and oats on the nose; follows onto the palate. A bit of malt on the finish with a touch of floral hops.

Light copper color... Aroma of earthy hops... Flavor is black and green tea, lots of earthy hop notes throughout... Enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

47,3 cl can @ some park, Amsterdam. Rated on 15.07.2014
Aroma has apricot, hay, fruity hops and hints of toffee. Flavour has hops, toffee, minerals and some fruits (apricot). Quite British for an American beer. Solid and rich Bitter to be only 4%. Somewhat uninspiring though.

16 oz. can from De Bierkoning @ home. Clear amber color. Uneven off white head with reasonable retention. Aromas: at first strong resin, fresh flowery hops, later some fruit (mandarin?) and caramel malts. Fruity hops retronasal, somewhat resinous and bitter. Flavor is light bitter, light fruity. Body is rather thin. Finish seems rather tasteless, but eventually some bitterness and resin appear. OK, the strength of this beer is in the aroma rather than the flavor.

This pours a copper color but has tons of floaters. Thin and slightly off-white head. Very little lacing. Aroma is nice...hoppy with hints of fresh cut grass, watermelon and citrus. Mouth feel is very watery. Almost no taste but a bit of tart bitterness. A bit of a dank basement flavor.

Can: Gold & burnt amber, hazy throughout & topped with a frothy, chunky, eggshell cap. Lightly bitter, grassy & floral aroma. Very clean, inviting, light, but refreshing. Small hints of mildly bitter citrus peel, melon, hint of white pepper. Taste is as clean & crisp as the smell would indicate. Hop leaves, freshly cut grass clippings with a mild weediness. Lightly peppered grapefruit rind, hints of peach, floral hops, & a zesty finish leaning towards some toasted biscuit & baked bready malt. A light but lovely session beer, I wish this was available to me all the time. One of the easiest drinking beers youll find.

16 oz. can pours a hazy caramel/orange color with small white head but lots of lacing. Aroma has orange peel, apricot and toffee. Taste is as bitter as expected, with slight sweetness in the middle and a bit of mint in the bitter hoppy aftertaste. Body is light to medium with average carbonation and a slightly sticky mouthfeel. Easier to drink than I thought it might be. A very good ESB
Can. Distinct toast and marmalade aromas. Pretty bitter for the style, but still definitely an ESB. Very tasty. I quite like this.

Tap at Sweet Peas. Caramel colored with a thin white head and heavy lacing. Caramel, orange juice, and a light lemon rind hop background. Body has a light sweetness followed by the light bitterness. Body is watery.

Can at barely legal tasting room 
thnx to vincent 
Pours fuzzy orange small white head 
Smell is bitter , orangy . 
Taste is dry orange , bit bitter , some dusty character .

Can:
Slightly hazy amber with a thick, beige head.
Orange-peel, toffee aroma.
Flavour is very malty..apricot, orange-cream.
Very soft, nice gentle bittering and fruitiness.
Really good.

Tap - small foamy head, medium copper color, pretty balanced aroma and flavor - biscuity malt backbone with a fair amount of earthy and fruity hops - pretty good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a slightly hazy orange, small head, good lacing. Aroma was nice and light with some lemon, tang, grapefruit, mango, honey, and some peach. Taste mainly followed the nose. Awesome light brew with a nice fruity taste perfect for summertime. Light body, perfect amount of bitterness, and a smooth finish. Very good.

Purchased at Bottles and Cans in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on a humid Monday June night after work and a walk. Appearance is a very cloudy dark gold with a rich and frothy white head. Aroma of passion fruit, light wheat, light floral, decent. Taste goes down with moderate syrup and bitterness, definitely fruity. Overall good offering.

Nice golden, colour with a really great creamy foamy white head that laces incredibly well. Aroma is lightly fruity, some oranges and apricot, some pepper as well. Mild caramel flavour, very easy to drink. Tough style to get high ratings on but its very expertly crafted beer.
Can. Light pepper, orange/apricot, and toffee malt aroma. Golden yellow with small head. Lightly sweet apricot malt and mildly bitter herbal orange peel flavor. Good.

I like this really light pale ale. Crushable and light n alcohol. Had out of a tall boy. Pours yellow and smells slightly hoppy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I don't get the high reviews. Tastes more like a kolsch. Light golden color. Grassy and light. Earthy. I guess it would be good for drinking many of in the sun. Not the case now

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2015 This is an updated review of the 2015 version of Bitter Brewer. This beer has been a favorite for several years, but this years example is hugely disappointing. No, not just disappointing; it is a major departure in the thin hop water direction of session ales. Ive kept my former review & numerical ratings below for anyone who is interested. My current ratings are what is reflected in this review. I sincerely hope Surly reconsiders their direction for this beer.

Hazy orange. White head, dissipates quickly, little/no lacing. Faint somewhat citrusy aroma. If the dry hopping was for aroma, it didnt do much. Initial taste is mild, transitioning to a very bitter, piney, orangy, borderline unpleasant aftertaste that hangs around much too long. So long, in fact, the astringent bitterness is still there long after I would like to take another drink. Mouth feel is thin, watery. Overall, this is a significant step backwards for what used to be one of my favorites. Im unlikely to buy it again.

Old review with rating:
A bit too high in hop bitterness to be a true English-style bitter, but otherwise, it is faithful to the style. I wish this was a year-round offering from Surly.

Can from Binnys. Poured bright golden with white. Aroma of light citrus. Very light carb med bod. Light bitter taste balanced. Sessionable

Can. Pours a medium burnt orange, off-white head with decent retention and lacing. Nose is mild citrus and malt, wet cardboard. Mouth is light and dry, soda crackers and mild grapefruit, florals, not much of a body. Good thirst quencher, but insanely overpriced for what it is. Ill stick with the Furious. Waiting for the puck to drop on game 5... Lets go Rangers!!

Apricot color. Fruity malt aroma. Taste - crackery English malt with some light fruity notes. Low bitterness, nice malt profile, light and drinkable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Thanks to SJ. Brew was good, but a bit thin. Nice notes of bitter hop, caramel malt and citrus fruit. Not bad at all.

From notes, consumed on 6/4/13. Can (dated 5/7/13) poured into a tulip. Pours a copper/golden honey brown with 2 and a half fingers of off-white head. Great lacing. Aromas of caramel, toffee, floral notes, grapefruit citrus, light honey. Tasting notes of wheat bread, floral notes, grapefruit citrus, light caramel and toffee. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

Hazy, burnt orange with a small, white head. The aroma is earthy with light fruit and some buttery popcorn. It has a light body with oily texture and lively carbonation. The taste is bitter with a slightly smooth finish. May have been a little old, but still not the best effort from Surly.
Can pours an amber orange with a small / medium head and thin lacing. Bitter hop aroma with lemon and citrus notes. A bit grainy with lemon, orange, and peach flavors. Not my favorite Surly.

Can @ Bruces. Picked up from CT Ave Liquor. The pours amber with a small head. rich toffee and cherry on the nose. Red fruits, brown bread. The taste is more bread, red fruit. Smooth, supple sweetness. Dry finish. Medium body, soft carb. Pretty solid.

Can, canned 05/23/13. Oh oh. Clear orange with a small white head that dissipates quickly with minimal lacing. Aroma is stale caramel, pine. Flavor is better than that, but still odd. Light sweet, almost a bit of lemon tart, light bitter. Need to finds a fresh one.
Can shared with northropfrye. Bitter and honey aroma. Taste is similarly sweet and bitter. Taste fades quickly though lingers a bit at the back of my tongue.

Beautiful orange body with foamy white head, some lacing. Snappy citrus and powered ice tea and strawberry aroma. Taste is initially bitter but with a disappointing watery/milky finish. Still not bad, but a weaker one by Surly standards.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 Great brew. Pours a nice dull burnt orange with sediment, head, and lacing. Aromas of bright citrus and tropical fruit. Similar flavors with some tang and citrus bitterness. Yum.

16oz can shared by JohnGonk. Pours a hazy orange color with a finger of off white head. Aroma is very herbal and lemony. Reminds me of Liptons lemon ice tea. Taste is the same. Lemons, orange zest, tea leaves, and herbal hops.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2015 From 16 oz can to small snifter (once in Oct. 2013 and again [but full can] in Oct. 2015). 

Hazy, murky golden-apricot body.  Looks and tastes a bit like grapefruit juice. 
Excellent aroma; lots of citrus/fruity aroma and flavor; dry. 

Weak spot: somewhat thin mouthfeel, but the carbonation level is good.

The beer pours great with a nice amber color that passes some light through it, has a nice white head that thins out but lingers around and leaves good lacing on the glass. The smell is decent with bitter malty flavor with a resin hoppy finish. The taste is great with a nice bready bitterness, a mild malty flavor, and a piney finish. The mouthfeel is great as the beer is well carbonated and the taste leaves you dry and bitter. Overall, a solid english bitter with a great finish and flavor to it.

Can, thanks to one of my co-workers for bringing it into town. Poured a nice, clear copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma was very light, caramel malts, not a whole lot of hop notes - enough to balance out the malt. Very light otherwise. Flavor was light caramel notes. This one was very drinkable and while its perhaps not robust or bold, the sessionablity of this one, with it remaining clean and enjoyable makes it quite a feat over other similar beers that retain a metallic or sickly element to it.

Pours a dark gold almost copper tinged with a small white head that fades away to a wisp.

Almost smells like an IPA. Very citrusy nose with slight hints of spice. Smells good, but Id call it abnormal for the style.

Starts off slightly citrusy, but not anywhere close to the nose. Light spicy bitterness invades the palate much earlier than normal, but never gets too intense. Very even bitterness all the way across the tongue. A very bready almost rye like as well sweetness hits after the initial hop burst before fading into the bitterness as well.

Mouthfeel is very fairly light with good carbonation levels. Very easy drinking beer.

Definitely a bitter beer, but never gets close to the palate wrecking ways of an IPA. Everything about the flavor is exactly what I would expect from a bitter. Another very good job by Surly.

Can. Some restrained citrus, herbs (maybe sage), and light blonde raisins. Dull brown color with a thin head like pancake batter. Light caramel / Brit-style maltiness comes through, with some metallic notes / finishes with a dose of hops, then balances, and then disappears. Thin-medium body. Good, low-alc, session stuff.

6th August 2013Tasting at Bruces pad. Hazy amber beer, small off white head. Palate is light, superfine carbonation. Neutral malt. Slighy floral note and light orangey citrus. Finishes softish and semi dry. Mild minerals. Flirting with bland but okay.

Pours golden orange with a light hop aroma. Flavor of biscuits and bitter hops but finishes bland 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pour at Surly during the RBSG. Crisp clear yellow in color with a white head. Nice bitterness. Not overbearing. Refreshing and clean. Easy drinking session brew.

Can thanks to khoffman43. Pours a hazy golden amber color with a small foamy head that fades normally to a ring. Aroma is grainy with peaches, apricots, and grass. Taste has a very light sweetness and moderate bitterness. Fresh peach and apricot hops mixed with a grainy malt base. Dry, crisp, bitter finish. In a blind taste I would think this is IPL. Lots of flavor packed into a light abv beer.

Can. Pours a cloudy orange amber hue with light white head. Looks unfiltered. Aroma of Sweet malts, orange and peach with a hoppy zing. Taste of malt, biscuit with some apricot and orange nice balanced hop finish. A refreshing bitter with great taste only coming in at 4%. Well done Surly!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can shared at Bruces, thanks to Jack, 06/08/13.
Hazed golden amber with a thin off white head.
Nose is hops, caramel malts, tropical fruit tang, sugars, very light pine.
Taste carries less depth, bready malt, light hops, bread dough, orange.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light bitter notes in the finish.
Drinkable affiar but ulitimately another mediocre ESB from a US brewer who cant resist throwing in a shit load of hops where they arent wanted !

text:
A hazy golden color with a touch of brown/orange. Finger of white head. Smells orange, apricot, some hoppy notes but a little subtle, other citrus smells as well, lemon. Taste is a little bitter, not much sweetness, some cracker/bread, orange, pretty tame flavors overall, a little watered down tasting. Not bad though, a decent drinker. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can, thanks to Jack at his farewell tasting. It pours golden amber with a small white head. The nose is pine, resin, varnish, juicy orange, peach, earth and light caramel. The taste is earth, wood, watery, leather, dry, twiggy and dull bitterness..... Finishes up rather dry indeed! Light-medium body and high carbonation. Pretty boring stuff.... a disappointment!
Great session brew. This style is starting to grow on me thanks to this Surly offering.

Can at Bruces in London during Jacks farewell tasting. Thanks to Jack! Pours mostly clear, orange-gold with a slight, creamy white head. Nose has so,e dry bread, dry pine and leaves, hints of dried orange. Light sweet flavor, lots of simple, dry citrus, dry bread. Light bodied with average carbonation. Dry finish, a bit more bread, kind of bland dry orange. Basic.

Can from Zipps Liquor. Pours orange with an inch of white foam. Big fruity aromas on the nose. The taste is more malty which is a 180 from the expectation created by the aroma. I quite kike that curve ball. The finish restores the fruitiness. Nice! Finally a bitter that kicks ass.

16oz can. Unfiltered glowing orange-copper color. Foamy, glass lacing head. Really has the peach, orange, apricot aroma as advertised. Clean, simple, mild, but has a lot of character. Significantly better and truer to style than most US variations. Capture an English feel, without being fishy or ringwood dominated. A great beer, would love to see this in six-packs.

Cloudy orange amber with light foam. Some floaties too. Malty aroma with a slight hop thing going. Great malty biscuit taste with a little hop in the finish. This is a great Bitter. The 4% makes it even better.

May 2013 can to a pint glass. Pours a honey/amber color with frothy off-white head. Lots of particulates, some quit large. Decent lacingAroma is slightly floral with bread, citrus and honey/caramel. Taste is sweeter than anticipated with an undercurrent of floral hops and some citrus and herbal qualities. Malty finish with only a little bitterness. Medium, slightly creamy mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pounder->English pint. Hazy orange with huge frothy white head. A: citrus, floral hops, bread, spice. T: malt with solid hop undertones. Very drinkable, though not particularly bitter.
Can. Orange pour with white head. Herbal and grassy hop aromas. Flavor is malty with almost no hop flavor.

16 ounce can at a sharing. Pours a cloudy darker orange with a nice white head. Aroma of florals, citrus, caramel, and malt. Taste is malt, topical fruits, florals, caramel, malt, and pine. Nice easy to drink beer.
Aromas of oranges and peaches. Hazy orange with a thin white head. Very crisp and bitter, sessionable.

Tap @ Grumpys NE. Pours a hazy bright orange appearance with an off white head. Soft citrusy, grapefruit, creamy, lightly sweet malty aroma. A bit light but very easy drinking, mild citrusy, a bit fruity, herbal, soft flavor. Easy drinking session ale.

16 oz can to half-pint glass (shared with the Mrs.; thanks mikem409). Looks good for the style; a hazy orange with thin white head that quickly dissipates into razor-thin lacing. Smells solid; doughy and hoppy with a fairly sweet backbone. Tastes like it smells with some more discernible fruit hops and a solid mouthfeel. A solid example of the style.

Bread and slight citrus nose.  flavor was really mellow compared to most surly beers I have tasted.  Really malty with some hops undertones.  Bread and light sweet fruitiness mostly. Not really that bitter.

1 pint can compliments of ZMDR1975. Hazy orange pour into a perfect pint glass. Nose of bread, earth and some sort of distant spice. Weaker than I would have hoped for on the palate, hardly any carbonation. Flavor of sour dough bread, some floral hops, and herbs. A bit of the bittering hops linger at the finish with a tea-like flavor hovering around. All around, quite average, but pretty drinkable.
Can from chase, thanks! Pours hazy orange amber, aroma is malt and citrus hops, taste is mild malt and hops, very balanced with smooth finish, nice

Can.  Hazy amber orange, with t Arjun white head.  Earthy, bready, doughy, and slight caramel aromas.  Dry, nicely bitter, doughy and earthy.  A well-balanced but interesting ESB.  Bit thin in the body, but overall solid.
Appearance golden with a white head. Aroma not much taste thin  and not interesting
From a 16 oz can shared at home.  Pours a clear gold with a thick white head.  Mild hop aroma.  Flavors of biscuit.  A bit thin.  OK, but not great.
Not my favorite Surly brew.  Tried this one on tap at Republic Uptown.  Biting bitters but without the pleasant aromas that other beers have.

Aroma is light pine, oats, caramel, and English malt. Taste is oat, caramel, English malt, and a nice light piney hop character. Very nice light drinker, lots of flavor for the low abv. Another great surly brew!

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. I'm pretty sure this batch of cans was improperly stores because the hop profile was a little dead and the whole thing was a bit off. Will re-rate this one when I can. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an opaque orange/amber with a medium lt tan head.  Aroma is very floral...some spicy hops and loads of peach and mango...hint of sweet caramel.  Flavor has earthy tea notes and pale malts atop mild hoppy spice and stonefruits...earthy bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and the finish is dry and bitter with mild orange tea.

500mL can, sent from khoffman43 (thanks Kyle), pours a clear dull copper with a medium foamy white head. Aroma of English biscuity malts, lots of floral soapy hops, and some toasted bread crusts. Flavour is quite restrained, with English biscuity malts, some dry floral hops and again the toasted bread crusts - nice and dry, with high sugar attenuation. Easy drinking session ale that doesnt invigorate the palate, but succeeds in being refreshing. Solid.
Pours amber with a white head and aroma of hops and grapefruit. Taste is of caramel, malt, hops, and pine with a subtle, slight bitter finish. Taste is very light, easy to drink, and a solid brew.
Pours a golden orange color, with a small head. Nose is aromatic with fresh grapefruit, pine, straw and honey. Beer is light and carbonation soft. Finish is dry and bitter, Quaff Score 7 / 10
tap at Muddy  Waters 2Oct2012, a dry hopped ESB? of course it smells great, and of course it tastes great, but its a quick hitter and gone before you know it. good stuff.
very good ESB.  great grassy, floral, sweet taste before the bitter comes in strong.  nice color.
Can. Pours peach with thick head and good retention. Aroma is citrus and caramel. Flavor is the same. Very nice sessionable ESB.

Can. Slightly hazy orange pour.  Quite citrusy with peaches, oranges and some other stuff tossed in. Hops are not super noticeable but add a little something. Not a bad beer but a style I dont care for.

Thanks to Steasy66 for the trade.
The pour is slightly hazy, medium gold color with a minimal off-white head.
The aroma is negligible. Soft malts very little hops.
The flavor is lightly bitter, some dryness that follows along to the finish. 
Medium bodied, well carbonated. Just not my style.

This beer pours with a warm, light orange-amber color and a big, fluffy, sticky head. The aroma provides a nice balance of sweet caramel malt and some light herbal hops. The flavor likewise blends fruity, sweet malts with a bright yet somehow musty combination of hops, and the light effervescence further lightens the flavor profile. Overall, this beer , has a nice earthy quality, but it is at the same time light, bright, sweet, and quite drinkable.
This is a great sipper.  Nice hop aroma, nice hop and malt flavor witha great palate.
Can.  Thanks to bnielsen13 for the can.  Pours a golden orange color with white head.  Malt, citrus, hoppy, vegetal aroma.  Bitter, earthy, citrus flavors.
Tap. Yellow/brown pour witha  big white head. Malt, pine and slight fruit on the nose. Tastes a bit like root beer.

Beer Bloggers Conference 2012 
Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Nice drinking bitter ale.  Easy hops nice malts this was a tasty brew.

Thin beige head which dissipated quickly. Hint of orange in the nose. Hazy dark amber. Somewhat one-dimensional bitter taste (reminds me of flax, of all things), but simplicity can be alright! Highly carbonated, so the taste and palate doesnt leave much of an impression.

A delicious and refreshing ESB. Aroma was weak and near nothing which is the only thing keeping this beer from being in the 4s. Theres caramel malt in there but you need to put your nose in the glass to find it. Pour was a nice light brown with a one finger off white head. Taste was nice. Its a session beer so its not big, but there was nice caramel, oatmeal and cereal flavors. Hints of ginger and orange came out as it warmed. Nice strong carbonation which Im sure the Europeans wouldnt like. Great beer.

text: light copper with a HUGE fluffy cloudy head that took its dear sweet time making way for the luscious beer. big citrus and sweet floral scents up front. a little more subtle with a light bitter flavor with light malts and more dominant hops. bitter finish. has a bit of an earthy flavor. a bit thin but good carbonation. low ABV and great flavor make this very sessionable. something i could drink whenever. i bet this is even better when fresh. Low abv, strong smell, but didnt come through on taste. Overall I believe that this was the worst beer I had in my set.

Marmalade upfront with a backing of pale and caramel malts, biscuit, some grassy hops, and fruit esters. Light and crisp.

Taste follows nose fairly closely. That interesting and delicious orange marmalade flavor upfront. Toffee and biscuit malt with some toffee.. Not a big hop profile, but wonderfully bitter throughout.

The feel is one of my favorite aspects of this beer. Its super smooth and the finish is nice and dry, leaving the slightest impression on the tongue.

Surly has it going on! Craft beer from the can is still a bit of an odd one for me. You couple this with craft beer in a tall boy and I am sold. Surly is not available in Ohio at this time so a special thanks goes out to Sud Savant for a mutually-beneficial trade.

Flavor is bitter, hoppy, grassy, peach (as noted in the description), with a clean, bitter finish. Very tasty.

Fresh bright grapefruity citrus hop immediately on nose. Crystal clear dark gold slight reddish tinge. Light head after intial one finger build. Flavor is intially subdued bitterness with a dry finish. Some malty carbonation with a flicker of sweetness leading to a crisp grapefruit hop with a dry finish. Nice.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 Dry and bitter, a bit astringent and watery, not as carbonated as I?d like. Mild sweetness. A bit disappointing for a Surly.
Pours a clear amber color with foamy off-white head.  Aroma is grapefruit, cracker,  bread. Taste is sweet and shapr crisp bitter.  Medium bodied and oily.  Pretty Tasty.
Orange with a white head. The aroma is citrusy hops and mild grains. The flavor is similar and very clean . Good stuff.
Fresh citrus smells with sweet and crisp hop tastes.  Well balanced and thoroughly enjoyable - great for this warm spring Chicago day.

Can-pours hazy orange with a nice fluffy whtie head that lasted the whole time of the beer-some nice carbonation as well.  nose of malts, mostly biscut, lite fruits and some lite earthy notes.  seems a bit more oxidized than i expected, especially since i herd this beer was very hop-forward on the nose and its only a month old!  however, what is here is very clean and fresh for the style-no arguments, but i expected something more over the top.  flavors are earthy, malty, lite pine, floral and musty hop flavors.  lots of flavors for a beer that is 4% thats for sure!  long lite bitter and sweet/woody finish with some lite floral character.  a fairly complex beer for this style however, i was expecting something that for me, would rate almost to a 4.  good nonetheless.

Can. Pours a dark orange color with a white head. Aroma is of lemon, citrus and orange, along with grassy notes and some caramel, sweet and biscuit malt and marmalade. The flavor follows the nose with orange and grassy hops, some caramel and sweet maltiness, with marmalade toasted malt and some chalky notes. The body is the lighter side of medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a pretty good ESB that blends America and the UK trends pretty well.

From the 5/2012 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled for a 16 oz can this beer poured an orange-caramel color with a medium sized foamy yellow-white head that left decent lacing. The aroma was piney and leathery with light notes of orange, bread and mushroom. The flavor was dryish, bitter and nutty with notes of orange and biscuit. Medium length dryish finish of orange and nut. Medium body though somewhat undercarbonated. Ok.

April 24, 2012 on tap at Valley Tap.  Orangish brown pour with minimal head and tiny bit of lacing.  Grainy, malt and citrus hops.  Taste was malty, then a sour bitter and finished with a soapy bitterness.  Some carbonation and medium body.

Hazy Dark Orange color. Very robust flavors of Marmalade, Yeasts, Floral Hops, and toasted malts; Perhaps the tastiest Bitter Brew I have ever tasted. Its light bodied and has almost no carbonation. It smells, looks, tastes and feels great. Another fine job by Surly!

This is what every session beer would offer in a perfect world...

Pours a hazy burnt gold with a half finger of white, milky head. Slow, steady beading.

The nose smells like my kitchen on a Sunday morning. Warm biscuits, cereal, subtle honey, sweet grain, wheat. Very inviting.

The taste highlights a lot of the same characteristics. Tons of biscuit and other soft, grainy bits. Buttered whole grain toast.

The feel is one of my favorite aspects of this beer. Its super smooth and the finish is nice and dry, leaving the slightest impression on the tongue.

Overall, I think this beer is too often overlooked. Very tasty and easy drinking.
I agree so much with Renoylds comment about lightly hopped water. This was not a hit for me, I will pick other Surlys first.

Pours a nice golden amber with a medium creamy  white head.  The nose is a nice bouquet of peach, orange, and mango with some notes of pine and resin.  The taste is fruity, tangy, citrusy, and hoppy with a long bitter dry finish.  This is a very tasty session beer.  I only wish it were easier to obtain.

Bitter Brewer pours a dark amber color.  Huge fluffy white head is poured.  Great retention on this one.  One more note is that if you look at the can, that is Todd, their brewer drawn on top.  Todd is an awesome guy.  Anyway back to our regular scheduled program.

The aroma on this beer is pleasant.  Not overwhelming.  Just a nice aroma.  The description on the site states that the malt and hops give off a toast and marmalade character.  I totally see that here.  Really nice toasted malt mixed in with some citrus hop aroma.  The mixture gives off a nice earthiness that I just loved.  Not as strong as other bitters Ive had but still really nice.

Taste is much the same.  A nice toasty malt taste.  Almost burnt.  Mixed in their is the citrus.  Its lovely.  I also picked up some caramel and a tea like flavor. 

Mouthfeel is light and refreshing.  Almost watery.  Has a dry feeling on the tongue.

Pint Can. Smells a little grassy/piney, probably not the beers fault but my gfs talapia stinks, and thats all I can smell. Looks a slightly cloudy amber. White head.  Must have been a short brew time. Tons of flavor for a 4% beer. Not bad.

Overrated?  I guess if youre looking for a session ale this is pretty decent but where are the malts?!  All I can taste is very lightly hopped water.  When I drink a bitter I expect good complex english malts and not absent pale malts... I hoped for more.
Tallboy, so Im giving this beer extra points for kicking ass. Great soft malty notes and a balancing unnoticeable.

Can to bottle. Great golden Orange color with an awesome thick head. The pour on this bad boy is awesome. Super clean and crisp finish. Great nose with some nice floral notes. There is so much to love about this beer. 

One of my go-tos in the summer. I love this beer. And for around $8, I love the price as well.

I received a 16oz can in a trade with a friend in Minnesota. I poured it into an English nonic pint glass.

Appearance: Hazy, tarnished orange hue but with plenty of visible carbonation. Forms a small, white, frothy head. Average retention and lacing.

Smell: Amazing hop presence with light citrus and flowers - almost like a perfume. Subtle sweet malty and confectionary notes buried underneath. 

Taste: Im always amazed when a brewery can do more with less and when brewers (usually Americans) can put entirely new spins on classic styles. Surly Bitter Brewer does both simultaneously: it doesnt forget its roots, yet it doesnt apologize for its overtly American qualities.

Usually light beers with strong hop presence tend to taste like hop water, but this one is a lot different. Sweet citrusy hop flavors begin and end the palate, yet it is not dry or bitter (only 37 IBUs). The English bitter palate is revealed throughout the middle with a strong flavor of grain, cereals, and red fruits. Its a juicy taste with a strong orange and apricot marmalade taste. The hops bookend the palate with a light citrus taste, and keep the fruit theme going without becoming distracting or cloying. 

Mouthfeel: Surprisingly thick and full-bodied, but it lacks the intensity and deadweight of a stronger beer. Mostly calm, but some noticeable carbonation. A short, pleasant aftertaste of jelly but for the most part its clean.

Drinkability: Its rare I find an American beer I could honestly see myself drinking for hours on end, but Surly Bitter Brewer is definitely such a beer. With a delectable palate of genuine taste that doesnt overwhelm and a comfortable mouthfeel and smooth, clean finish its the epitome of drinker-friendly. Its not strong enough to stand up to a hearty meal, but as the pub beer its meant to emulate it does the job perfectly.

Pours a clear golden orange/amber color with a two finger, frothy off-white head that slowly fades into a thin ring. A decent amount of lacing left behind. 

Sweet citrus hop aroma with subtle grassy pine countered by pale malt character. The nose is almost all citrus with hints of grapefruit, pineapple and lots of orange peel. 

Medium bodied with lots of sweet citrus hop flavor up front that lingers over the pale malt backbone into a slightly dry finish. The hop profile is one dimensional without much bitterness and not very dry. More sweet than anything with hints of tropical fruit and citrus peel countered by biscuity malts. Well balanced but not overly complex.

A surprise delight.  Have been a big fan of Surly Furious, which is curently number 1 on my favorite list.  Bitter Brewer is has a hint of lime.  The upfront bitter note is not overpowering, and the beer has a very nice finish.

16 oz can.  Misty amber with an off-white head.  Nose is distinctly orange marmalade, like it says on the label.  A little musty with marjoram.  Slick body with sharp carb prickles.  Taste is slightly sour wild strawberry, orange peel and lemon-lime soda.  Flavorwise an imperial bitter.  Cant believe this is only 4%.  Wow.

16oz can, as an extra!  Pours out a great off orange/copper hue.  Wonderful bitter aromas, citrus, pine, really nothing aggressive, but pleasent.  Palate is fantastic, jumps right off the bat with a lingering bitterness around the edge.  Amazing and balanced.  My favorite bitter to date.

Thanks to GatorGuy92 for the share on this one.  Pours a hazy orange with a white head.  Nose is orange, apricot, light malt, some grass, and a very nice citrus bouquet.  Flavor is very, very light for what I smelled.  I get orange, apricots, some slight grass, and light malt.  Flavor bursts with citrus and then fades off.  It is a big surprise how ephemeral the front of the flavor is, but this sessionable beer is definitely one to ponder and drink several.  At 4.1%, very nice sessionable beer.

Can from Dennis Brothers. Pours honey colored with a slight head. A lot of under-head carbonation. Aroma has some grassy pine, some caramel and some resin. Taste brings sweet caramel, some pine, some earthiness. Not much "bitterness" - although some - but a nice clean, crisp, light, flavorful brew.

Canned 28JUL11

A: pours orange with an ephemeral foam cap finishing in a central dome over this excellently clarified beer. No lace. (3)
S: Some citric hops over a malty base layer. The malts may be a hint oxidized and it shows with a cardboard character. (3)
T: Lots of pale malts and some nice sweetness from the oats give this a rural taste. Subtle and simple. (3.5)
M: Thin with hi carb. The carb is sharp and a little too much for the body. Semi dry finish. (3)
O: I could take it or leave it. I make a mild ale actually that is similar to this. I wouldnt call it world class, but certainly sessionable. (3.5)

From BA.

Found a single 4pk of this hiding in the liquor store the other day (2/14/2011)! No date. Accompanying my stir-fry lunch.

Appearance:
a golden-orange, pretty much clear. Little visible carbonation. A finger of head at first, but it disappeared leaving no lacing.

Smell:
Fruity, kind of reminds me of mango or pineapple, like fresh tropical fruit juice. Sweet and tangy aromas.

Taste:
Maltiness gets you first, which gives way to a dryish pineapple flavor. Despite the smell, not really sweet at all. Taste gives way to a pleasant and balanced bitterness, again reminding me of pineapple.

Mouthfeel:
Feels like fruit juice, but it doesnt stick to you like orange juice does. Very clean and crisp.

Drinkability:
Super-high. This tastes refreshing, smells refreshing, just feels refreshing. Right now Im drinking it to rebel against winter, which pretty much says that its a fantastic summer beer.

Oddly enough, I didnt care for this beer as much when I first tried it last July. Maybe my palette just needed some development, because now I think this one is fantastic.

Got this lovely 16oz can in trade.  Pour is vibrant hazy orange with off white head.  Nose is sweet cut grass and apricots.  Taste is bitter smack and clean bite.  Lots of lingering but not messy.  Lots of lagerness to it.

Pours a deep transparent amber orange with a large bubbled cream colored head.  The nose is very hoppy, orange peel and leafy hop with a bit of stale biscuity bread up front and notes of tea.  The flavor is less hoppy and has a bit of an empty finish, very tea like, some herbal leafy hops, with some underlying biscuit.  Thin body, well carbonated, lacks depth in finish.

Canette de 500 ml. Arômes très fruités (ananas, écorce doranges) et floraux, belle présence de malt légèrement grillé. Robe orangée et trouble, effervescence moyenne et peu de mousse. En bouche, on retrouve un très bel équilibre entre un houblon rappelant la marmelade et un malt présentant de belles notes de pain grillé. La bière est relativement mince en bouche, mais très goûteuse. Finale bien sèche agrémentée dune amertume dintensité moyenne. Très bon !
UPDATED: SEP 28, 2011 Tap at SurlyFest. Pours a light caramel. Has a hint of fruit (apple?) with little after taste. Very good.

A fair to midland bitter. The nose is far better than the taste. Very mild and unassuming. Very easy to drink. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Big boy can sent from Alpar, poured an amazing amber color with a thick white head.  Has a malt/toasty aroma with a hint of peach, and apricot comming through.  Had a nice citrusy flavor and a nice sessionable beer.

Tallboy can from online beer store that shall not be mentioned!  Pours clear orangey copper with a thin, short-lived white head.  Aroma is fresh hops, subdued pine, and a touch of peaches.  Solid malt backbone gives good balance up front before a wave of wet and dry hop flavors rush forward.  I suppose the loads of malt help categorize this as an ESB, but to me it reads more like a fresh harvest IPA.  Good, but I had visions of Bitch Creek and this came across similar to Sierra Nevada Harvest.

16oz canned June 6, 2011.  Served at around 45F.

Pours lightly hazy amber with a one finger white heat that recedes to a small cap and leaves some nice rings of lacing behind.

Aroma is lemon, apricot, some grass and bread.  Moderate strength...kind of weak.

Flavor is lemon, orange, apricot, and some grassy hops, cracker & bready malt backbone, finishes with a real nice bitterness.

Mouthfeel is light-medium bodied, with ample carbonation.

Man this hits the spot after a long day of work on a sticky Georgia summer day.  Nice flavor and surprising bitterness for a low ABV session brew.

Can thanks to secret santa. Nearly brilliant golden to light amber pour with a large, fluffy, slightly off-white head. Toasty and bready malt aroma, lots of fruity esters, berries, currants, tea and marmalade. Citrusy, light husky, stone fruit and candied orange peel (hop) aromas. Light peanutshell huskiness. Flavors are malt forward, toasty, grainy, bready, just slightly husky. Tea and marmalade. A hint of citrus, light tropical fruits from both hops and esters. Medium bitterness, but just enough to balance. A solid mineral character. Medium carbonation, fuller body for such a light beer. No alcohol, very easy. Doesnt feel very authentic, but it is very sessionable and tasty!

16 oz can from a trade with CLevar. Pours hazy burnt orange color with off white head. Tropical fruit aroma with some bready malts. Moderate bitterness with the warrior hops dominating. Light to medium body with average carbonation. Very nice. I could drink lots of this on hot summer days.. Thanks Caleb.

Tasted 6/6/11. 16oz Can. Sampled with phaleslu and others! Filtered with an amber golden hue. Webbed off-white head. Aromas of bitter grapefruit, cut grass and a subtle piney, resinous malt bill. Medium bodied with an odd rubbery note. Citrus rind and pitted fruit. Totally bitter and tangy. Mild malts and a mild citrus flavor. Astringent and heavy, but the palate is both bitter and sweet.

Pours a nice apricot/copper with off-white head.  Nice bouquet of floral/citrus hops and in the background a sweet, caramelized fruit.  The first few tastes, the bitterness seemed to come through - smooth, but thin in flavor.  Further into the can the malt comes out more - sweet, fruity, honey.  Bitterness hangs on the tongue a bit.  Very light on the palate as expected.  Very clean.  A hard transition from big beers, but good in its own way.  Have to be in the right mood, I guess.
Has a golden color, nice pleasant smell, a nice soft bitter hop taste to it.

Courtesy of DalzAle.  Super fresh, canned on 5/25.  Dark orange pour with a modest pillowy white head.  Aroma had bits of mild fruity hops, light peach, some bready malt, nice balance.  Flavors started out with a decent bitter hop punch, then some light notes of peach came through, fruity finish, bittersweet.  Light to medium bodied, nice level of carbonation.  Excellent stuff, Surly has sold me.

16 oz. can via BA trade. Pours a cloudy, dull amber color with a small white ring for a head, plus a little bit of film. Aroma of grassy hops, toast, crackers, pepper, citrus, and herbs. Very nice. Flavor of light malts, tea, grassy hops, lemon citrus, and toast. Very light bodied, with medium carbonation and a watery, tea-like mouthfeel. Really nice session ESB, right on the money.

YES! Thanks to Honus Wagner this beer was super fresh. Amazing nose, lacing and taste. Bitter grapefruit citrus hops, english biscuit malt, the smell the dry hopping adds is a treat. Can not believe how awesome this beer is.

Can. Poured into a NB tulip style glass a clear darker copper color with a 2 finger ever so slightly tan whitish head. Bready, citrus, slight pine all in the nose, nothing too extreme but nice from such a low abv beer. The flavors again are fairly nice given the abv. Light citrus and a breadiness make up the majority of the flavor. Ends with a slight bitterness. Light/medium mouthfeel. I really, really wish they made this all year!

Can.  Ive had it before, but never got around to rating it.  Pours a nice gold, and tastes superb.  I could drink these all day (isnt that the point).  Hoppy enough to let you know what youre drinking, without being overkill.

On tap into 4oz tasting tulip...Poured a light, clear and watery copper with light head that doesnt last...The aroma and taste to me are super generic versions of an English ipa. Sugar and caramel come through mostly with watery metallic hops on the back. The feel is too watery. Surly mostly nails it, but to me this is a macro versions attempt at an esb.

16 oz can.

Pours a med-dark amber/gold with a soapy white head that dissipates quickly.

The smell is fruity and lightly hopped with a malty backbone.

The taste has a bit more citrus than normal, a bit yeasty note, some ok malts, not my favorite though. Not any bitterness at all.

Its a good session beer, a flavorful one at that. Probably the best session beer if you stick by the "4%" hard rule.

I had 3 more of these, and I totally appreciate this brew so much more, just fantastic.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-09-2010 01:56:00

Copper, decent white head. Light citrus, herbal esters up front, dry cracker, bread background. Flavor much the same, light crystal malt sweetness, clean. Well done, spot on, esb though is not my thing.

Poured into a Delirium snifter glass it had a brown orange hue to it. Hazy and cloudy with a thin head. Aroma that is slightly hoppy with a touch of sweet malt. Light body with a slightly peppery hoppy flavor.
Not my favorite Surly offering. I expected a high IBU.. am I wrong in feeling that way? I felt the brew was tasty with good carbonation and undertones, but just hit me as a little too mellow.

Can. Pour is hazy copper amber with a soapy white head that leaves subtle lacing. Aroma is faint and subtle lemon zest and grassy florals. Taste is a smooth lemon citrus flavor that wraps up bitter and earthy malt. Palate is thin to medium mouthfeel and solid carbonation and finishes chaulky. Not great, but not bad.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL.

A: Poured a nice copper color with an off-white head and some pretty good lacing.

S: Lots of mild citrus scents melding together atop a nice bready malt base.

T: Slight bitterness and a little bit of malt. Nothing super complex, but blends together nicely.

M: Light-bodied and well-carbonated.

D: Quite drinkable, as is the tradition of the style. Not my favorite of Surlys, but a solid attempt at this style.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-01-2009

Can purchased at Zipps. Pours a clear orange with a thick off-white head. Malty nose with some floral hops and a bit of citrus. Creamy malt flavor with some corn character, a bit of fruit and a grassy hop finish.
Can courtesy of DalzAle, thanks much Greg.  Ive never been a huge fan of ESBs, but this beer is definitely drinkable.  Its a little light on the palate for me, but all in all, I could do a few.
I almost hate to rate this since Im not a fan of this style. I think you have to love this style to enjoy this beer. It is a dumper for me, but my buddies enjoyed it.

1 pint can shared by shigadeyo.  Pours a clear dark golden color with a large creamy white head. The aroma is toasted grains and crisp orange citrus and pine.  The flavor is more toasted grains, crisp grapefruit citrus, mild pine with a moderate level of bitterness.  Light-medium bodied.  Very drinkable if it was more accessible.

fresh can courtesy of ty, thanks! decent pour, overall a decent beer. not my favorite style, but still very drinkable. lots of citrus and some light sweet bready notes in the taste. a tad watery in the back palate, but a nice sweet aftertaste and slightly oily finish help to compensate.
Pours a dark orange. Aroma is hoppy citrus, peach, and orange. Taste is bitter hops. Peach and apricots. Palate is medium mouthfeel. Clamy. Overall a solid brew

Appearance:  Pours a hazy copper with a thin white film of head, leaving creamy spotty lacing. Within the body, you can see visible rising carbonation.

Aroma:  Herbal and citrus hops, iced tea with lemon.

Taste:  Delicious hoppy water or hop tea.  Very herbal and refreshing.

Mouthfeel: Thin,watery and fizzy.

Overall: Pretty bad ass for a 4 percent ale. This really captures the hops well.

Can.  Pours clear dark amber with a white head that fades to minimal lacing. Has an aroma of light caramel malts, some hops.  Tastes like crystal malts and clean bitterness.  No offensive flavors.  Goes down smooth.  I will reach for this as a session beer over any other Surly.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2011 It took me nearly the entire can to realize how good and interesting this beer really is.  Its got great color and lacing.  An interesting, slightly grassy and slightly fruity nose.  The body is perfectly smooth.  And the flavors mix some of the nice lighter hop flavors from the nose with a good malt profile.  I think that having this one warm up a bit does it a lot of good; the Brits should be proud.

E: Brand spanking new can thanks to Armin.  Oh.  My. God.

Can.   Pours a beautiful golden color with a fluffly white head and oodles of lacing as it went down, appearance is just about perfect.   Aroma is floral, some citrus, and light grains.   Flavor is light lemon, floral hops, tea-like notes, and hay.   Palate is light bodied, creamy texture, finished bitter and refreshing.   Great beer, true to the style.   This is my new session beer for the ages!

16oz can pours a totally transparent, burnt orange with a frothy, creamy, lacing white head.  Nose is nose is malty, crackers, bread dough, some pitted fruits, some light pine.  Flavor is a little on the watery side, malt, biscuits, orangina, iced tea, a little pine tar way at the end.  Finish is watery and lightly sweet.  Its not bad, its just not interesting.
Pours a pale orange with a small white head. The aroma is citric and very similar to earl gray tea. The flavor has lemon, grapefruit and burgamot. Simple and pleasant.

Can. Pours amber with thin head off-white head, lacing. Intense pine and earth hop aroma right upon opening. Upon pouring some complex floral and pine hop scent unfolds, along with fruity malt and a distinct hint of smokiness. Flavor is malt dominated with a good hoppy background. Grain flavors are lightly fruity, roasty, just a slight bit of tartness. Hops are clean, full citrus flavors. Ends with just the right amount of bitterness and fresh citrus flavor lingering in the finish. A wonderful interpretation of the ESB style, clean and crisp, very drinkable with just an element of roasty malt complexity to keep things interesting.

Can - courtesy of tytoanderso. Amber pour with a moderate beige head. Hoppy nose with lemony notes, citrus oils and ripe fruit (light peach, mainly). Taste is light lemon, unripened peach, tea leaves, hops and earthy notes. Light spicy hops as well. Body is light-medium with soft carbonation. Ends with more peach and lemon, iced tea, earthy hops, citrus oils and soft grains.

can through trade poured a medium orange amber in color with a thin coating of white head. aroma has some nice mellow dry hops, citrus, mid range bitterness, and some tea. mouth feel is light and crisp with a high carbonation. flavor gets a bit more bitterness going, bitter tea, mild dry hops, light citrus, and a twang of sweetness. a nice easy drinker and it has plenty of flavor for a 4% beer. quite enjoyed!
Not my favorite bitter, but a great example of the style nonetheless. Its very bitter with a very mellowed hop profile. Shows that bitters are very different from IPAs when done correctly.

Fom trade with Kbutler1.  Floral hops, toasted and caramel malts.  Some citrus, not as much as expected.  The appearance is a clear amber, off-white head.  The flavor is strange, toasted malt, black tea.  Moderate hop bittering on the finish, which hangs in there for a bit.  Somewhat thin in body, a little watery.  Not my favorite style, but not bad.
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2010 Piney citrus hops sweet and resinous.  Pours pale amber with a thin white head.  Grassy hops with caramel malts, mild taste but great session beer!
Sampled at OBF 2010. Floral aroma. Bitterness starts off muted then grows with each sip. Pours a pretty orange color. A little on the watery side for my taste.

Tap at OBF, poured clear amber with a white head that left quite a bit of lacing. Aromanis of light citrus fruit but also slightly chemical. Flavor is crisp hops, the warrior definitely dominates, very thin body but quite drinkable.
Tap @ OBF...  Poured amber with a white head.  A simple brew, hoppy, malty, with a touch of sweetness with a leafy, lettuce-like quality and a mild bitterness.

16 oz can.  Pours a clear copper body with a great frothy off-white head that left some sparce lacing as it receded.  Nice bright hoppy nose over a toasty and lightly caramel malt base.  Smells a touch like brewed iced tea.  Nice bitterness level for the heft of the body, Very well balanced, the malt is pretty light and the hops arent overdone.  Crisp sharp finish that just begs you take another big gulp as soon as possible.  Light bodied with nice soft fizzy carbonation.  Very very drinkable.  I could plow through a 4 pack of this in one session pretty quick.
Can. Courtesy of Skyview. Nose is Earl Gry tea, pink peppercorns, lemon, light hops, slight malt undertones. Flavors of tea, grapefruit, some hops, odd....

Weak colour pale amber. Notmuch head. Aroma is very earthy, it smells likev tea, earl gray tea. Flavour is abrupt. Not a bitter. Very citrus and earthy. I am not very impressed with this it is very weak.

Smells like tea. WTH? Theres some citrus and hops in there... Some head on pour, not too great looking. Quite grapefruity in flavour. A Lot! leaves the same taste in your mouth, grapegruit and tea. okay, not great.
Can, thanks tarheels. Pours amber with a big off-white head. Flavor is nothing but iced tea. Didnt care for it. Might be good with a shot of firefly dropped in it and chugged.

Can thanks to Santa. You rock! Pours a clear light amber with a thick, yellow head that has good retention and decent lace. Lemon tea aroma. Taste is watery, slight oatmeal, English breakfast tea. Decent.

Pours golden with a nice white head. The aroma is earthy bitter with some pine and citrus. The flavor is dry and spicy with notes of spicy hops and tea leaves. There is some hints of citrus before a piney finish. Very easy drinking yet satisfying hop forward beer.

Can  pours a muted amber with a good froathy off white head.  The head lasts well.  Produces spotty lacing.  Has a clean like soap, hoppy aroma.  Some caramel and grains.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is lightly hopped with good mouthfeel.  Easy drinking.  A light body.  The texture is sticky.  Has a good finish with a nice aftertaste.
golden, clear, tan foam, caramel, bread, toast, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish,

Can from kmweaver.  Dark orange-brown pour with a slight haze.  Light tan head.  Lots of hops on the nose.  Lots of grass with some pine.  Very dry and hoppy finish.  Piny, herbal, and grassy.  Really nice and easy to drink.

Can. Clear amber body with frothy, off-white head, mostly diminishing. Moderate aroma of caramel, toasted grain, herbs, earthiness. The flavor is lightly bitter and lightly sweet. It finishes lightly to moderately bitter and lightly sweet. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Dry, bitter finish. Muted caramel for an ESB. Instead, the taste is dominated by grain. Less refined than classic bitters. That aside, flavorful for a 4% beer. Easy drinking.

From can. Pours light amber, orange highlights. Medium white froth drops fairly quickly. Aroma shows nice fruit esters - tangerine?, soft caramel, and slight graininess. Flavor is initially sweet and fruity with just enough bitterness for balance.  Dry finish with lingering english malt biscuit/breadiness. Medium light body, slight astringency. CO2 is high for british styles, but does right by the US of A. And now the charcoal from my grill is overwhelming my nose and wrecking my palate.
Thanks to ArminJewell for sending these my way.  Great brew.  Light and crisp, packing a huge hop punch without going over the top in any one area.  Easy drinking.  Almost the perfect brew.  YUM!

On tap at Nomad last Friday.  Pours golden orange, with a thin head that disappears quickly.  Honestly, I could not pick up an aroma on this beer at all.  Perhaps because people were smoking nearby.  Bummer, because I was hoping for big hops.  The flavor and palate were really interesting, though.  Like grapefruit and pine nuts, pretty thin, with a bitter finish.  Quite enjoyable!  Ill definitely drink this one again when I want something refreshing.

Can thanks to tytoanderso, thanks man!  Poured a clear golden-copper color with an inch thick, fluffy off-white head that quickly faded to a bubbly layer.  Aroma of light pale malts, some soft citrus, including orange flesh and some light apricot, and a lightly earthy, piny hoppiness.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry with some light biscuit and soft hints of peach and orange lead into a crisp, earthy hoppiness with some light undertones of pine paired with an orange fruitiness that linger into a crisp, dry finish where a faint toastiness is present.  Light, crisp carbonation and soft mouth feel that is topped off with a nice dryness.  Overall, this is definitely my favorite ESB to this date, although it may not be exactly true to style.  Thanks again Ty!

Pretty disappointed in this beer. I waited a while to try this beer only to be let down by surly. I never thought that was possible because of all the other great beers they have brewed. It pours well with an off white head. Grassy aroma with light citrus and malt notes. It is bitter for only 37 IBUs but taste watered down. I can see why they brew it in the summer for drinkability but not a favorite of mine. I would take a bitter on the golf course over a bud any day though.

16 oz can from the Four Firkins.  Beautiful golden/orange pour with a nice fluffy white head.  Aroma and flavor are both slightly hoppy with notes of orange and other citrus.  Finish is a slight bitter bite.  Great summer beer!

Fairly tame for a surly brew, or rather, a surly lover. There is a crisp bitterness with a hard to place citrus/lemon flavor matched with somewhat of an oatey taste. This may please some, but it leaves a non-descriptive bitterness...bitterness is the point, but I guess I would like a better taste.

Poured from a can into a pint glass.  Orange to brown in color.  Small white head that quickly dissipates, but leaves a thin layer atop the beer.  Aroma is toasted bread and fruity with a nice hop presence.  Flavor is bready, light fruitiness, and finishes with a bitter hop taste.  I could easily see myself putting down a bunch of these on any given occasion.

Can poured a clear golden amber with a small lingering ivory head. Aromas of graininess, earthiness and light carmel. Palate was light bodied anmd smooth. Flavors of carmel, grainines and earthiness with a smooth moderatly bitter finish.

Sampled on 5/7/2010. This ESB pours a medium orange gold color from a 16oz can. Medium sized white foamy head, with nice lacing and good retention. The aroma is fruity (apricot and peaches), floral and hoppy. A medium bodied bitter/ESB. The malts are fruity and sweet, with lots of peach and apricot flavors. The hops are floral and citrusy. Nice hop profile. Good carbonation. Nice not to bitter hoppy finish. Lot of flavor for a 4.0% beer. Yeah, if I could get this it would be a nice session ale. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

A: The pour is absolutely beautiful. A hazy burnt orange color with a fluffy cream colored head which clings to glass.

S: The nose has a nice sweet citrus aroma with a mild pine and some bready malt notes. Theres also perhaps a slight grassy hop scent to the beer which I notice when I got to take a sip.

T: The flavor is subtly hoppy with sweet orange and miscellaneous citrus along with a mild bitterness on the finish. Theres also a toasty, biscuity malt flavor which is the backbone of the beer.

M: The body is perhaps a bit thin with a low to moderate carbonation.

D: This is a fairly new style to me, but one that Im enjoying more and more. I really like the subtle flavors and mildness of it which make this beer a really easy drinker.

Thanks to hophead101 for sending me this beer.

Pours a slightly murky yellow with a white head. The aroma is wet grass with some oranges, but overall it is a little faint. The flavor is pineapple, orange and some grassyness. The beer is slightly bitter. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Overall, a lot of flavor is a 4 percent ABV package.

Thanks Santa!  Pours a slightly hazy orangey copper, thin white head that leaves decent lacing.  Nose is black tea, orange marmalade, caramel, dusty barley - reminds me a bit of the smell when Im milling grain for homebrew.  Flavor is more of the same but the fruit is more peach than orange.  A really nice malt hit comes forward for a second before being swallowed up by black tea bitterness and a bit of caramel.

Can: Amber in color, somewhat hazy, moderate to large foamy off-white head, spotty lacing, light carbonation. &nbsp Subtle straw and alfalfa on the nose. &nbsp Very rind oriented on the tongue. &nbsp Very much like the white bits 

of an Orange, but not as biting or citrusy. &nbsp Otherwise, straw/haw presense. &nbsp Somewhat heavy on the tongue, not as bright or floral as other Bitter/ESB examples. &nbsp Finishes with a touch of cereal butteryness. &nbsp Odd 

considering this is a new brew. &nbsp Not all that strong, but its there. &nbsp Lingering rind. &nbsp Not a bad beer, but not what I was expecting. &nbsp Thanks Bob for the can!

An unexpected treat from Surly.  Pours hazy golden with stark white head.  Aroma is full of lemon and citrus zest, and flavor is a blast of refreshing orange, apricot, peach, and lemon.  The hop and zest tastes lead into a nice sweetness, and ends refreshing and a bit bitter.  An excellent brew that is underrated!
Clear amber, thin white head fades. Lemon and wheat aroma. Same earthy taste with a thin lemony body. Awesome can.

Can thanks to brian23456 (BA)!Transparent amber with a thin white head. Nose has light earth, leaf, and hop with vague touches of bread loaves. Heavy tea in the flavor and strong lemon and pineapple through the rather empty finish. Not much of an opinion either way here.

Can shared by JoeTheYounger.  Pours hazy orange with a thin white head.  Aroma is mostly nuts and citrus.  Flavor is mellow with some lemony citrus and a smooth malt backbone.  Light to medium bodied with generous carbonation.

can thanks to allendodd. Honey colored pour, thick rocky head. aroma of flowers, citrus, orange zest, resin, pine. Flavor has slight spice, nice and hoppy. Definitely taste the marmelade mentioned on the can. Really good sessionable beer.  thanks dodd.

11/04/2009:  Surly Bitter Brewer... Aroma:  Weak pine hops and subtle toasted underlying malt.  Appearance:  Faint yellow color; chill haze; small white head; fine lacing.  Flavor:  Unique, unexpected, and interesting blend of lemon, pine and spruce (LOTS!), and toasted malts; hint of cumin.  Palate:  Medium-light.  Overall:  I REALLY like this beer - its crisp, refreshing, plenty flavorful, and very unique and memorable.

1 pint can ( 4% Alc/Vol; IBU - 37 ) via trade from Skyview.  Thanks Bob!  Rating #230 for this beer.

can, pours light amber with a tall frothy off white head.  Aroma is nice and citrusy with lemon peel and orange.  Wow, so good and at 4%, has tons of flavor.  Soft pale malt sweetness, the oats are there as well with a nice fresh hop finish that ends dry with a nice piney hop note.  This is a great session brew.

Poured from can into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Dull orange-gold, very thin head, looks flat but expected for style.

Citrus due to dry-hopping, leading to a stronger smell than typical for style. Also, faint malts detected.

Clean toasted, tea-like malt taste balanced by metallic hop bitterness. Light citrus flavor that is less evident in the taste than smell.

Low carbonation, firm and dry. This is where most American attempts fall short; Surly nailed it.

Very easy to drink and at 4% abv, it is an ideal session beer.

Bartered bottle from Hophead22. Poured a cloudy orange color (like the can) with small white head. Aroma was nutty and citrus hops. Flavor was toasty, malty, dry. Pallet was fizzy medium. This was pretty good for a session beer. Thanks Tim.

Can from allendodd. Purveyor of Surly to the needy masses. Thanks! Pours a slightly hazy amber with a frothy off-white head. Very floral aroma above some sweet lightly roasted caramel. Less than medium body. Sharpish carbonation. Its so floral its perfumey. Very strong light stone fruit notes. Finishes with a rather citric bitter. Other than the body, I think it fits the style. Like it a lot.

slightly hazy golden color with a touch of orange.  low-med carbonation, big head with lots of lacing.  upon tasting you are immediatly struck with a nose of dry sharp hops.  Overall mouthfeel is surprisingly watery.  notes of grain and peach in the flavor.  Overall its ok, tastes a lot more like a pale ale than a bitter.  Prob wont be buying this expensive beer again.

1  pint can courtesy of tytoanderso. Pours a cloudy copper color with a big sudsy white head that has great retention and ample lacing. The nose is soft with filberts, apricots and earthy hops. The taste is similarly nutty with some biscuit filling in the back end. The hops profile is only moderately biter at best. The palate is a bit thinner than I would have preferred. The finish is dry, long and mildly biter. Overall: A very enjoyable ESB.

Source:500 mL can courtesy of hellomynameis. 
Glass:Pint. 
Appearance:Clear amber pour with a two finger white head.
Aroma:Nutty malt with a hint of citrus. 
Flavor:Nutty malt base with grains, fruit and caramel. 
Palate:Medium body with solid carbonation.
Overall:This was good, but hard to take an American bitter seriously.

16 oz. can - thanks to tytoanderso for the trade; clear amber with fluffy white head; fruity hops, juice and sweet malts; grainy, fruity and a little oat; plums or grapes too; I kind of like the fruity edge, but its quite strange at the same time

16 oz can via Mys Swap 4 (thanks skyview!). pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head. The aromas are earthy hops and toasty grains. Taste is tea, caramel, lime, orange-peal, hay and earthy/herbal notes. Body is light, carbonation is high, too high for my enjoyment of this style. I think if they tone the warrior hops down a little, or use a different hop, and the carbonation WAY down, this would be a good beer.
Deep golden color out of the can with a foamy off-white head.  Fresh juicey citrus hop nose.  Raw hop pellet and grain flavor.  Thinnish beer.  Easy drinking but the flavors seem a little disjointed.

Can from Ty. Poured into a pint glass, good head. Pale orangish in color. Aroma of some bitter hops, duh? Taste is a light (thin) bodied hoppy beer. Nice little fruitiness to it. Light malts, well balanced. Really easy to drink. Actually a nice session beer that could be drank any where. Thanks ty for the brewski!

A competent bitter but the least convincing of four Surlys sampled at a group tasting in Sydney, courtesy of Oslo. The use of American hops leave this some distance from being a traditional British bitter - but given the general standard of canned British bitters, that may not be such a bad thing. Soft fruits dominate the aroma and flavours - peach and apricot mainly. Bit soapy and indistinct, I thought. Perfectly drinkable but I wouldnt reach for this if there was a half-decent alternative. (Can courtesy of Oslo - thanks buddy - at the Milson Point park session September 09)

Lightly hazed amber to bronze in color liquid. Tall, lasting cream colored head. LIght caramel, grass, pine and citric pith scents. I find the citrus a bit on the "raw" side and hard to embrace. Still a full of aroma. LIght butterscotch start. Middle has plenty of hops with floral, grassy and citric flavors all jumping in and out. A bit of apricot  in the finish. LInger is rather clean and only a small amount of bitterness left on the tongue. A nice session ale, perhaps a bit too much fruit for me.
600ml can, courtesy of Oslo, Ratebeer tasting under the Bridge 12/9.  Really good full flavour and bitterness for a 4% beer.  Nice bready oats aromas.

This canned brew from a  rating party poured a very large sized head of foamy fine to large sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent golden brown colored body and a thick foamy lacing. The aroma was malty musty and dirty sock. The semi-flat mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt mild hops and mild bitterness. An OK brew just nothing special.

Very fresh floral hop aroma,very surprising, the best effects of well done dry hopping,almost expect this to be an imperial IPA,flavor is surprisingly balanced and smooth ,almost a lager like texture ,all the hopping in the aroma ,settled nicely in background and bittering hops take center stage ,remarkably drinkable for such a fragrant brew,excellent

16oz can from theisti. Nose is really pleasant bread/biscuit malt with a nice citric bitterness. Really a pleasant smelling beer. Taste is extremely well balanced english malts, apricot as advertised, with a really nice bitter dry hoppiness to finish. Could drink many, many more of these if it were available here. Perfect ballgame beer. Thanks, Tim!

16oz can courtesy of thesti.  Pours a clear light orangish brown with a nice size white head that leaves some lacing on the way down.  Nose is bready slightly sweet malt with some sweet floral and slight citrus notes.  Body is light but refreshing with good carbonation.  Bready malt and semi sweet up front with apricot notes.  Quickly goes into nice bittering with the bready malt backing staying throughout.  Great bitter that is easy drinking.  Great session beer that I would drink this any time if it where readily available to me.  Thanks Tim!

16 oz. can acquired via trade with tennisjoel.  Pours dark orange/yellow with a foamy off-white head.  Interesting floral hop aroma mixed with a fruity sweetness (cherries? maybe peaches?).  Taste is mildly hopped and mildly sweet.  I dont have much experience with this style but it does feel like something is missing.  Most likely, given my other experiences with Surly and the high rating in its category, this represents the style well but its not really for me.  Not a bad beer by a long shot but I want more hops.

Murky red/gold liquid with that great Surly head. Oddly low carbonation visuals in my Sam Adams sensory glass.

Smells of mild malt goodness, almost like a tea. No booze presence.

Taste is mild, as it should be, making for an easy drinker. Light hop presence and of course malt that I cant discern.

Mouth is medium in body and carbonation. Goes down easy and smooth.

My first of this style is a pleasant one!

on cask in the real ale tent at GTMW
Murky off orange pour w/ no real head.  Great big hop aroma, lots and lots of fruits (citrus, maybe a hint of lime zest) and a hit of grass.  Sweet caramels come through after my nose adjusted.  Pal was only avg.  Flavor is not as good as the aroma.  Lightly bittered, easy to drink, std ESB.  I could do it as a session.

4%, can. nose is soft breads cut with a squirt of pure lime juice.  appearance is sandy blonde with light cotton candy head. body is thin despite lacing and voluminous head.  flavor is of floral hops and subtle bready malt.  fades fast and leaves bitter and clean.

Can sample at Noogfest High 5. Poured amber with an off-white head. Aroma of sweet tea with lots of lemon and a slight pine background. The flavor was maltier with hints of wood and hops. Medium body.

Thanks to Dansting for this one. 16oz can served in a shaker pint. Poured a clear gold with less than a finger of fine bubbled, white head. Fresh citrus hop aroma. Light bodied with some malt backbone. A little malt sweetness. Nicely hopped, but not overly bitter. Lingering hop dryness to the finish. Very drinkable. Making a flavorful, lower alcohol beer is a tribute to the skills of the brewery IMHO.

I wish more breweries would make beers like this instead of taking it to the other extreme of alcohol and hops. One session beer in the lineup isnt too much to ask, is it?
