Pours a clear light amber with a dense, creamy off-white head. Light aromas of tea and flowers. Flavor similar, balance between a lightly resinous tea in the malt, and a light, floral hops profile. I can see where the brewers description is coming from in calling the hops flavor apricot or orange, but it comes across more floral to me. Medium body, lightly carbonated, smooth palate.

Can thanks to CanIHave4Beers.... thanks, Andy!  A flavorful 4% beer in a can... this beer is a dream!  Pours clear light orange with one-finger off-white head.  Lovely citric hop profile on the nose and similar on the palate with nice bitter bite.  Some mild peach/apricot notes as well.  Light palate, but great carbonation.  Refreshing, and didnt give me a buzz even though I drank it down pretty quickly after exercising.  If this were easily available, I would drink so much of this beer...
This was very drinkable but a little two-dimensional. Citrus aroma and flavors, dry finish, a bit thin on flavor to me.
16oz can poured into a pint glass.  Interesting and good. A nice caramelly grain flavor balanced well with hop flavor and bitterness.

16oz. can.  Fresh sample.  Aroma is almost fully hoppy, with abundant piney, citric, spicy notes along with faint touches of dried apricot and pale, toasty malt.  Clear light-medium amber color with a lasting, fine head, nice lacing as well.  Flavor profile is quite hoppy and bitter throughout, the malts lending only hints of pale grains and biscuit, the hops easily dominating with their strongly spicy, grassy, herbal flavors and finishing with pure leafy, resinous bitterness.  Mouthfeel is effervescent and very dry, body is light.  Refreshing and drinkable but quite one-dimensional.  Cheers to Eugene!

Can shared by Evan by way of Hophead22 at Hangar 24.. Pours golden with a fluffy white head..Floral hops and a hint of soap... Citrus hop bite with a dry finish.. Thin and very carbonated.. I really like this one.. I think Im gonna start trading for Surly now.. Thanks alot Tim for bringing this back.. Asshole!!
Goloden with a small white head. Aroma of citrus, tangerine and apricot. Sweet juicy American hop and caramel flavour.

16oz can. Dark gold with a fluffy white head.Malty, toasty aroma, very clean. Nice bitterness,more than most bitters Ive had, but very drinkable. This would be a staple beer for me if available, very good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 16 oz can brought back from Minnesota by my lovely friend Kathy. Pours out a hazy golden color with a minimal white head. Aroma is very fruity: peach, orange and apricot with a hint of oat and biscuit. Flavor is fruity and full of grains, and the mouth is light and very refreshing on a hot summer night. One of the best examples of this style Ive ever had.

Pours a bright orangish color with a good head and some lace. The smell is nice and fresh, some peaches, some citrus, plenty of fresh hops. The flavor is somewhat grainy and malty with again some good fresh hoppiness and that good peachy fruity flavor. Delicious.

Can sample at Noogfest High 5.

Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that lasted with good lacing. Moderate tart citrus hoppy aroma. Medium body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium bitter flavor with a medium spicy bitter finish of moderate duration.

Solid drinkable beer.
While low in abv, this bitter is far superior to its English cousins. Fruity, tasty, with a nice mildness.

Orange with a thin off white head that leaves splotchy lacing.  Aroma of earthy hops, citrus, pine, caramel and pale malt.  Taste of fruit, light caramel, mild earthy and citrus hops.  Moderate bitterness on the back end.
Sampled at the Noogfest High 5.   Light and fruity, semi-farmy.  Aroma is better than the flavor. Good bitterness, but too much lemon.  Awesome can though.
Light gold/brown pour with slightly off white head and lace. Aroma is malt earthy hops and a hint of fish? Very light malt with a subtle finishing bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation.

Noogfest High 5. Sample from a can thanks to unclejedi.  Solid copper-orange thin white head.  Aroma is big herbal bitter, nice hoppiness, awesome aroma, the taste disappoints, just kind watery, some caramel, spicy pine hop finish.
@Noogfest High5-16oz can-pours a white ring for a head and gold color.  Aroma is sweet light malt, pine.  Taste is sweet light malt, pine.

Very, very good beer. A bit hoppy for the style, but its good hoppiness. Pours a nice orange-gold, with a medium, creamy head. Aroma is quite citrusy and piney, then some floral notes emerge and a pleasant malt base shows through the hops. The flavor is maltier than the nose, nice and smooth, with some grassy and citrus hops in the finish. The palate is fairly full, with dense but very fine carbonation. This would be an exceptional session brew.

Poured a golden orange. 
Nose of stone fruits, floral, and strong citrus. 
Taste is bright of citrus, hops, light biscuit flavors.

Tap. Poured light cloudy brown with an off-white head. Aroma was bitter with some grainy notes, perhaps oats and just a bit of sweet citrus. Flavor was a very nice balance of malts and hops as the flavor began malty but hops kicked in throughout. A nice beer.

Can - Pours deep amber with a nice tan head. There are citrusy hops with some sweet caramelly malt on the nose. Its fresh and inviting--this is a beer I want to drink. Taste is grapefruit hops and sweet malt, that doesnt linger on the finish. The taste is pretty much gone the instant you swallow. Man..I could drink these all night. Its a refreshing beer thats tasty without being too over the top in any one area.

This poured an orange color with a white head. The aroma was floral with a malty presence. Caramel and citrus in there. The flavor contains some citrus, caramel and a hint of pine. The palate was a bit weak on this one. Overall not bad but they do alot better.

on draft at busters on 28th.  Pour a golden orange color with no head.  Lots of bubbles in this one.  Smell of nectorines, flowers and citrus.  Taste is crisp and clean with a nice hop finish.  Very balanced beer!

Can, thanks to tytoanderso. Aroma opens with juicy hop notes, sort of green-grape-like, grapefruit to put a more conventional hop aroma on things, then moves onto some caramel malt, somewhat doughy, not all that toasty for the style (not that I care). Flavor again has a distinct green grape hop feel for me as well as some orange oil, and other vaguely fruity notes arising from the sweet malt. Rather thin/watery mouthfeel for me, though looking at it a different way, that could only add to its sessionability, which is high considering my rare desire for more of the same beer after finishing this one. Quite tasty, and certainly a unique take on the style.

can.  Mostly clear golden orange with a small off white head with good lacing.  Aromas of light citrus hops, light spice and biscuit.  Very light and clean flavor and finish.  Another good one from Surly.

Thanks to skinny guy for forwarding this one. Somehow the hops here are a little muted. For something called bitter I am expecting a little more going on with the hop profile, possible explanation is that it is a bit passed its prime but only another can will tell me that. Who is sending me one?! Clear golden color. Aroma is mostly toasty grain, barley with a bit of grassy and spicy notes. Light bready malt flavors up front give way to a citrus hop flavor with some apple and other fruits in there as well. The finish is a bitter pine sort of flavor. Perfect for grilling out back which is what I did with this guy.

Pours a lightly cloudy orange with a medium, off-white head with some lacing. Aroma if of sweet, fruity hops and bread. Pleasant mouthfeel with light carbonation and medium-thin body. Tastes of fruity, citrus hops, bread, earthy and pine notes, peach, orange, mangos, other sweet fruit flavors, and spicy, peppery notes. Bitter finish. Quite a good beer.

Pint size can from skinny guy. Pours a bright orangish kinda copper color with a white head. Nose is quite fruity, lots of apricot, some orange, very fruity. Palate is velvety a bit with some nice carbonation and a pleasant mouth feel. Flavors are fruity and creamy. Peaches, apricots, light sweet cream notes, some hints of bitter hops and a nice clean bitter finish.
Above average for the style. Good easy drinking, plenty of hop character. Enough effervescence to propel an aroma and a little more. What English beer could be! ha!

Sweet orange and malt aromas. Brownish orange color with an off white head.  Flavor is ice tea, with a light fruitiness and a bitter finish. Palate is light and slightly watery.  Not enough punch for me.  Refreshing, but not too exciting.

Can.  Pours a clear orangish-amber color with a white head.  Aroma of bready malt, citrusy hops, and black tea.  Flavor more of the same, with more American hop aroma/flavor than your typical English ESB.  Nice citrus/tropical fruit notes.  Medium palate with soft carbonation.  Great for the style.

Can at PPRBSG09.  Pours a clear orange with a white head.  Aroma of orange juice, citrus, melon, and iced tea.  Flavor is slightly watery with melon and citrus notes.  Its ok, but kinda meh.
6/4/6/3/13 (3.2/5)

Can: Golden orange with an off white head. Biscuity aroma with a crackery dryness and a mix of British and U.S. hop varieties. Very dry and muted flavor. Light crackery notes with just a kiss of husk. Some herbal hop bitterness. Simple, but very solid and sessionable.

Can at PilsnerPeters Spring Gathering.  Pours a slightly hazy orange with a thin white head.  Pineapple and grapefruit on the nose.  Thin, with a light bitterness.  Started off strong, ended rather meh.

can at Ft Wayne tasting - Pours hazy orange-gold with a lingering white head.  The aroma is mainly of citrus hops.  Tastes moderately hoppy with citrus notes.  Theres also an odd earthy character that I didnt appreciate.  Its on the watery side and doesnt have enough malt character.  I love bitter beers, but this brew doesnt do it for me.  Its uneven and lacking.  If this can was typical, then I dont get the high ratings for it.
PPRBSG09. Can.  Pours a  copper white body body with a floral spicy pepper hop character and a dry earthy bitterness.  This sets out to do exactly what it wants, v.bitter.
Can thanks to tytoanderso.  Pours a murky orange with thick off-white head.  Aroma somewhat weak, but pleasant of citrus hops and a sourness.  Flavor matches pretty well, a nice refreshing beverage.
50 cl can, Fargo, ND, USA. Faintly hazy amber colour, citrus yeast and pine aroma. Minimal carbonation lets the flavor through, most english style of bitter Ive tried from an US brewer. Very nice.

2009 Can - Thanks skinnyguy! - Pours a coppery orange with a medium white head....aroma is hop flowers, pine, oranges and a bit of grain...flavour is clean and bitter, lingering hops and light caramel malt...great summer brew...

Can thanks to DalzAle.  Aroma has notes of resin, flowers, and citrus hops.  Medium copper hue with a small white foamy head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is sweet and finishes decently bitter.  Palate is med-light bodied and soft.  Good brew!

pours otherwise rather ugly looking... coppery golden brown with a soapy whitish head with some moderate drips and splotches of foam. 

the nose is very floral... orange blossoms, peaches, pale malt sweetness, lots of wood, earth, dry spiciness and faint non resinous pine. 

the flavor is the same... very dry, floral and bitter with a  spiced finish. hoppy bitterness lingers. 

seemingly light bodied with a rich slick mouth feel... i could drink this all day! at 4.2% i realistically could! 8/3/8/4/16/3.9

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge. Light orange pour with a white, persistent head . Floral aroma of resin and chamomile. Flavor is amazing tasty hops, some fruit, some tea. Creamy mouthfeel. Great finish.  Basically, really awesome ESB.

16 oz can shared with Todd during DLD 09 weekend.  Pours a clear light amber with a medium off white head.  Beautiful floral aroma with hints of pine resin.  Taste is very floral with hints of pine and bitter hops.  The aroma on this one is killer.

Can into an imperial pint glass. Pours a light orange/yellow with a thinner head. Aroma is of pine and citrus and maybe a bit of peach but I think I just have that in my head after reading the description on the can. Hops flavor predominates up front and fades nicely -not too fast or slow. Feels a little thin in the mouth. Took me a few cans (on different ocassions) to really like it.

A- Pours a deep orange color with a huge, pillowy off white head which leaves a lot of lacing on the way down.

S- Huge floral hop notes, some sweet fruit and mixed spices.

T- Taste mimics the nose, starting off with big, full hop notes and ending with a creamy finish. Not as assertive as i expected from the nose but good none the less.

M- Fairly thin bodied with carbonation on the low side.

D- This is an incredible session beer. If it was available around here I would make it my go to. I didnt know a beer under 5 percent alcohol could have this kind of hop profile without being incredibly bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2014 On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL. for their Surly 3rd Anniv. gathering. Pint served a deep gold with a nice foamy head and curtain-like lacing coating the glass. The aroma was a little sweetness, malt, citrus, and pine. The flavor added to these some mid-tone fruit and a pleasant dryness and bitterness that lasted to the finish. Medium to light body and very sessionable. Recently poured a pint can to a shaker at Lunar Brewing Co., with a very similar impression  as previously, adding an expressive, hop cone scent to the nose, and a bit of tartness & light apricot to the taste. Maybe somewhat soft textured, but consistently flavorful, and very sessionable.

Many thanks to Bob for the can!  Poured slightly hazy medium orange with a creamy, well-retained cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up floral, peach, and lesser earthy hoppage over pale malts and a bit of toffee.. very fresh and green impression from the dry-hopping.. soft and near perfectly balanced.  The flavor opened with lightly sour pale malts, dried flowers, and citrus bitterness.. pale and bready malts supported.. finished with more of the floral and citrus bitterness.  Lighter-bodied with high carbonation that worked for the style.. lasting residual bitterness on the finish.. mighty refreshing!

Can courtesy of Tytoanderso.

Pours a hazy golden color with a nice white head. Aroma is faded hops, apricot, malt, citrus. Flavor is hops, citrus, caramel, apricot. Very refreshing and drinkable and finishes with a nice fruity bitter characteristic. Good session beer.

Orange body with a white head.  Aroma is grapefruit and pine hops making that pretty nice.  The flavor is nice and malty, but the hops are nicely present giving the finish an earthy hoppy bitter.  Also is a little thin at times.  Very drinkable, sessionable beer though that I wish I did have just sitting around all the time to drink.

Wow, lots apricot, peach, and tangerine, unlike any other beer Ive had. A little bit of sweet malt hiding underneath the hops in the aroma of this. Definitely lacking body, almost watery. Flavor of the hops is not nearly as good though or maybe its just the mix with the malt. The malt (victory-ashtray) has that ESB dirtiness to it, but its not working here. Pretty good carbonation level. The bitterness in the finish is pretty solid though.

Poured a hazed gold with a small off-white head.  Mild citrus hop over a mild toasty malt.  The flavor is light but tasty.  Citrus hops are mild-moderate but do dominate.  Lightly bitter on the finish.  Very drinkable and good taste with a light body.  I am just not a big session drinker.  Now if you iced it. ;)

Pours a bright orange color with a huge pillowy, cream colored head that shows good retention and eventually settles to a thin film. The aroma is of piney and citrus hops over a toasted caramel malt base. The flavor follows with pine resin and orange citrus hop flavors balanced out nicely by the sweet, toasted caramel malts. Medium-light bodied with moderate carbonation and really easy to drink. The finish is dry with a lingering bitterness. Not as hoppy as I thought, but I porbably need to try a fresher can. Still a really tasty and very light session beer.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2011 TAP: dirty gold/amber pour, some malt and pine hop on the nose, mildly hop/bitter on taste. Some iced tea in here. Very sessionable and very nice on a hot day.

CASK: also had this on cask - tasted pretty dull and flat this way, not sure this is the best way to try this particular beer.

Can with thanks to skyview.  Pours a medium amber with a small/medium head.  Aromas are a mix of blue spruce and citrus.  Flavor is heavy with hops... and they basically match the nose.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but this is good stuff.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Can.  Slightly hazy orange pour, medium carbonation with an ashy orange aroma.  Flavor is peach, citrus and hops and finished nice and bitter on the aftertaste.  A decent brew, I just dont think this is my favorite style.

Can @ chrisos Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a malty floral hoppy aroma with some hints of caramel. Sweetish malty bitter hoppy flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a slightly thin mouthfeel. Has a sweetish malty bitter hoppy finish.

Pours a nice hazy orange/amber color.  Aroma is full of citrus(grapefruit) caramel malt and some grassy notes.  Flavor is both hoppy and full of malt.  This is the way an ESB should taste IMO.  Damn this is a smooth easy drinker.

Can. Pours a cloudy amber, nice off-white head, lacing is beautiful. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus and malt hiding in the background. Flavor is a very nice slightly sweet malt and a nice palate of grapefruit, maybe a touch of orange and peach. Thin, but very nice session beer.
Can thanks to Skyview.  Pours dark gold with smaller white head.  Earthy hoppy nose.  Flavor is big up front with bitter hops that goes a little watery before a toasted hoppy finish.

Light amber in color with a small white head. Aroma is like sticking your nose in a bag of fresh hops with some notes of grass and fruit. Taste is like water with hops in it with a slightly fruity finish.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2013 12 ounce can courtesy of cdumler. Thanks! Pours a slightly hazy orange yellow color Small head with low head retention, but nice lacing also. Aroma is spicy and herbal hops with some toasted hops and graininess. Taste is bitter hops and an absurd level of graininess. Very reminiscent of club soda. Faint caramel in the finish. Medium bodied.

Can. An unclear amber beer with a lazing orangey head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of grapefruit as well as medium notes of caramel and malt. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of spices, grapefruit, and more, leaidng to a slightly bitter finish. The body is a bit thin. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Can.
Hazy orange coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, pine needles and grape fruits.
Hoppy flavour of grape fruits and pine needles.
Dry hoppy finish.

(Can 45 cl) Courtesy of iowaherkey. Pours a slightly hazy amber golden with an off-white head. Fresh, citrusy hop aroma. Light body with a little nuttiness but otherwise completely dominated by fresh, dry citrusy hop notes. An excellent session quaffer. 131108

Courtesy of Styles
Can: The aroma contains light grapefruit, with some faint citrus notes.  It pours a transparent amber with a small off-white head that fades to a thin film.  The flavor starts with some faint citrus and toasty/grainy notes and finishes with mild grapefruit and floral hops.  Light-medium bodied with mild carbonation.

16 oz can courtesy of a Drnk_McDermott trade. Pours a nice auburn-orangey hazy hue with a really big bubbly offwhite / custard colored head. Aromas are of a nice prominent citrusy hoppiness coupled with a decent lighter sweet malt bill. Taste is more muted, some nice light malt upfront,a little more light bodied than expected, moving quickly to a nice hoppy bitterness mixed with some fruity notes (Orange, tamer than say, a grapefruity hop). Apricot and a mellow biscuity maltiness in the finish. Enjoyable and well balanced, albeit a bit understated in flavor, but then again at a touch over 4% (The same % as a Macro Light Lager), this thing is tops. Cheers!
Smooth, light, crisp, clean. Very good bitter. I am not so schooled as far as bitters go but I like this one. Just what I wanted form a bitter. Not "hoppy" but nice and bitter.

Can, thanks to kosko20.  Amber pour, some white head.  Aroma is lightly toasted grainy malt, and grass.  Slightly sweet and fruity malt flavor, some more of the toasted grain, and grassy / earthy hops.  Lightly bitter finish.  Decent beer.

Aroma is orange with some underlying malt, amber, pours a small custard head. Softer flavour of orange and malt than the nose suggested. Light bodied, well balanced. Very good example. Thanks Eric from Biergotter.

Can 50cl. @ chris_os Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008.Clear medium amber color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, moderate hoppy, grapefruit, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (020808)
Not sure how to take this one. Thin body with hops in the forefront. But, the hops seemed...off somehow. Had this right after a can of Furious, so I am not sure how anything could have held up.

16 oz. can, gotta love that. Pours a healthy head over a bright orange beer, with a few active columns of bubbles. Nice apricot and grass hop smell. Foam settles to a rocky head as I write this. Certainly the hoppiest tasting ESB I’ve found in my relatively few tastes of this style. A more grassy taste of fresh hops in the front of the tongue, basic bitterness in the back. Yet the malt base seems to me a little lacking. Sure, that’s partly due to its lower alcohol, but it kind of turns watery and metallic. A few other raters noted this, I see, and put it down to being served too cold, and I did pull this from the fridge. I can’t bring myself to rate this too highly for now, but I have more I can try under different conditions.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2008 Can Post RBSG 08 O-Town/Vero Beach Throwdown Chapter 8 Clear light golden ale with a small, frothy, white head. Spotty retention. Earthy, fruity aroma tenders interesting notes of honey, pepper and, of all things, Fruit Loops® cereal. Light to medium-bodied with lively carbonation. The flavor is a bit grainy and perfectly balanced. Crisp, lightly spicy, mostly clean finish. Thanks go out to SoLan for bringing the cans to share!
16 ounce can from kegbear. Pours a nice frothy white head. NIce orangish citrus aroma. The taste is very nicely balanced hop. So good. I would love to have this everyday.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Peach ice tea with a twist of lemon aroma.  Fairly malty yet dry flavor.  Tons of fruit aromas and dried, dry fruit flavors with lemon zest.

The sixteen ounce can comfortable pours into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip glass with a frothy, initially two-finger thick pale tan colored head.  The beer is a full amber hue that shows a lightly hazed, red tinged, dark copper color when held up to the light.  The aroma is nice an punchy with hop notes of ruby-red grapefruit, vibrant orange zest and a substantial, toasty, biscuit like malt character.  It is quite interesting how much this smells like orange marmalade, the hop character is just so nice and definitely hits the spot (and I haven’t even tasted this yet).

A little too cold still (near 40°F / 4.5°C), this tastes of lemons and hop bitterness.  As it slowly warms the hop-citrus flavors become a bit fuller, with notes leaning a bit more towards grapefruit.  This beer is quite dry, which is not unexpected considering the strength.  A touch more malt sweetness might accent the hop fruit character a bit more, but I like how light and quaffable this is right now.  There is just enough malt sweetness to this though to make the overall hop effect just fruity enough; touches of lychee, sweet grapefruit, ripe tangerine and some flowery peach notes all get more and more noticeable as this beer opens up.  The malt is not quite as assertively aggressive as it was in the aroma, but still there are substantial flavors of biscuit-like malt, and pale toasted grain that add complexity to this brew.

This is just too easy to drink.  The aroma is fantastic and I wish the flavor was a little more assertive, but this definitely needs to be on the warm side of 50°F / 10°C to be fully experienced properly.  I would kill to have this on hand pulled cask for a pint or five in a row.  This is a very good beer, that really would be at its best as a real ale; I would love to have that, but I know that is never going to happen.  Way before I want it to happen, this beer has disappeared from my glass.
Canned sample from Pisctaor (via Oakbluff).  Check out Pisctaor’s rating.  If he gave it a 3.7 it must be good.

Courtesy of McBackus.  poured form a 16oz can into a widemouth glass.  nose is very hoppy, very earthy and peppery spice.  pours opaque light copper and is very easy drinking.  slight bitterness fades quickly, but left me with some afterburning indigestion.  this beer did have a stlight metallic taste, but I can’t tell if that is from the can or maybe the hops.  overall a nice beer, but I was expecting more bitterness.

Pours a cloudy tangerine/iced tea colour. Moderate off white head. Nose- orange pekoe tea leaves, marmalade. Taste- sweet marmalade on whole wheat toast. Aspirin dryness on the finish. Light bodied with moderate carbonation. For sure the most flavourful 4.5% beer I’ve had the pleasure of trying.
Pours an amber/orangish color. Aroma of sweet fruit and hops. Nice malt flavors with a lingering citrusy taste. Well balanced, with moderate carbonation. Finish is obviously very bitter.
Cloudy amber pour with a thick white head. Grassy citrus hop aroma. Nice bitter hop taste with a good malt balance. Very good session beer, low abv and just really tasty.
Can. Big thanks to Santa for this one. Poured a light brown copper body with huge head. Aroma is hoppy and malty. Flavor is sweet malt, hops, and caramel.

Can:  Pours a orange copper color with a smaller white head.  Aroma is malty and earthy, a bit of florals.  Flavor is more malty than bitter, some caramel malt and fruitiness make the floral bitters a touch mellow.  Nice wet sensation.  This is not quite as bitter as expected, but still a pleasant summer ale.  Thanks Tyler!

[1600-20080816] 1pt can. Sweet rose water aroma is quite similar to marmalade. Slightly hazy, light orange brown body with quick foamy white bubbles. Sweet watered-down marmalade flavour is kind of old. Light-medium body is thin. Interesting marmalade characteristic, OK but weird.
(@ Cole’s IPA Festival; Buffalo, NY; c/o swoopjones via Sammy)
Bottle at Chris o’samber ... ligyt fruity hop nose ... fruity hop quite bready little pine

2008-08-16. Orange body with a small beige head. aroma of mild malt, grains, light buttery caramel, light floral hops, a touch of marmalade was the hesitant consensus around the table. Flavour has a light bitterness throughout, muted caramel malts, light citrus. (6+) Average palate. Decent overall, but nondescript. Perhaps pushing its due date?Can, shared by Swoopjones c/o Sammy

This will be my attempt to satisfy Ross guidelines for a proper rating entry.  Grimreeser was passing through Nashville and decided to stop by for a tasting and to do some trades. I decided to try this beer as I sat in my kitchen, planning for my upcoming business trip. This is a 16 ounce can, 4% alcohol and 35 Ibus. I do not have the born on date- sorry. This pours into my IPA tulip glass a slightly hazy amber, about 12 lovibond (under flourescent lighting) with a 2 1/8" pale yellow beige head. This head took about 4 minutes to dissipate into a 3/16" head, and left webby lacing. This has a nice fruity nose, with notes of exotic fruits like apricot, tangerine, and pineapple. The has light to medium body, but with a thin texture and soft to average carbonation. Initial flavor of iced tea, caramel, and toffee that quickly transitions to a very sharp grassy and spicy bitterness. Finish is hoppy and dry with a lingering pepper bite at the back of the mouth, which seems to subside as the beer reach about 50 degrees. Very dry and overly bitter for a typical British ESB. Perhaps a cask version could smooth this out a tad, but this is worth trying. And Ross, I did not have 22 ounces, but I did drink the entire can and I hope that will be sufficient to warrant a rating.   rating #120 . Thanks for the beer Chad

Nice golden amber with a white head that lasts a good while.  I love a beer that actually fills a pint glass!  Really great smell for an ESB or any beer really.  Sweet floral and grassy hops with nice biscuity malts.  Taste is a really great smooth combination of the above smells.  Really well blended and a nice lingering bitterness.  A great ESB.  Floral, grassy hops and the same great biscuity malt as in the smell but better. Goes down nice and smooth. Lively carbonation and a medium to light mouthfeel.  This is just one of the most quaffable beers I’ve ever had. At 4% you could have them all night. Another extremely great entry by Surly. They are quickly becoming my favorite brewery but they are so far away!

Can shared with Rudolf, Frylock, Mabel & Jerc. Most generously donated by Sammy. Not sure if this was past its prime or a bad batch. Pretty weak. Tastes of tea & sweet marmalade. Little to no bitterness. Not much going on here. will have to rerate as I have really enjoyed all their previous beers Ive had

Can at Blackfriers at m,y leaving do and at chris_o’s pre GBBF "TASTING". Aroma is vastly grapefruit, like super uber grapefruit, awsome and the taste is balanced with grapefruit and im just like oh yes, oh yes.

Courtesy SoLan.  Pours a pretty clear amber color, with a small off white head.  Smells real lively and spicy, some clove, and hops blended together.  Also, got a bit of black pepper in there too.  Real light and easy drinking.  The black pepper spice is quite evident I thought mixed in with the musty hops and a bit of grapefruit citrus.  Kind of tasted like an English style bitter or ESB which it is.  Nice little session brew.

A Mes rate: Bottle at Chris Os Pre GBBF TastingBright golden amber with a thin white head. Massive grassy hop aroma. Resinous and full of spruce. Lovely malt backbone. A glorious smell. Sadly the flavour is not a patch. It’s close to a five actually. Metallic, mineral and rather watery. Sod it, it’s a 5. Decent but too much metal and nothing like an ESB.

Appearance: Thin white head, a hazy copper that fades to a light gold in color when head to light.  Aroma:  wow thats good, extremely balanced of hops, fruits, and barely.  Flavor:  I taste coffee when it first hits my tongue, then hops kick in flavor with the fruit backgrounds...apricot mostly.  Palate:  what do you expect, the name is bitter brewer so it ends bitter!  But not overly bitter, just the right amount.  Its smooth, easy to down.  This one has impressed me.  Very complex in its aroma, not as much in flavor but still has its hidden traits.  Overall, I love it.  If head would be slightly larger and last, it would be a 5.

Finally a Surly beer that exceeded my expectations!!!  Oh, coffee bender did that too.  Surly rules.

can from tyrndo:  pours a clean golden honey colour with a big pithy dull white head. leaves some lacing.  aroma is excellent full of earthy hops and a great fruitiness apricots and some floralness also hiding behind all of the slpendor is a some malt. flavour is eal nice full of fruit apricots again, grassy hops and a slight bread flavour the malt is holding htis all together very well. another excellent offering in a can from surly.
Canned. Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is grass, flowery and fruity hops along with mild notes f vanilla. Flavour is flowery, fruity and wellbalanced. A quite mouthdrying brew.

Draft at Piece Brewery & Pizzeria. Poured a clear dark orange/brown color. The head was thick, fluffy, and white with good retention and lacing. Smelled of citrus, caramel, and light grass. Light to medium bodied and dry with mild to moderate hop bitterness of about 4 out of 10. The flavor profile was fruit dominated and included the likes of citrus fruits, mango, and subdued pineapple. There was also a distinct black tea note. A citrus-tropical iced tea, if you will.
pours a cloudy light brown.  scent is of lots of hops and a little citrus.  taste is also of lots of hops.  I wuld purchase this again.  nice brew.
real bitter brew.  slight dark brown and orange color.  Aroma is pretty hoppy but that was the main flavor. good brew. would buy again.

A gift can from oakbluff (thanks, buddy!). Hazy light orange in colour with medium carbonation. Huge floral hop aroma, with an almost to the point of being wit-bier-like soapy quality. The hops take on a decidedly more grapefruit flavor in the mouth, and work well against the grainy malt backdrop. There’s a great last ing leafy bitterness too. A lightweight Furious... but pretty damn good in its own right.

Can at Chris_o Pre GBBF Shindig 08.  I love these Surly canned beers.  Copper colour, lasting beige head.  Lots of hops on aroma.  Good leafy hop, but it doesn’t stand up in the mouth.  Some toffee on the malts.  Dies a bit after that good pink grapefruit aroma.  Goes to show it takes a lot of skill to make a tasty lower ABV beer.

Thanks Bobby for bringing with you on your visit. Pours mostly big creamy soap bubble white head, onto light yellow body.Some citrus and fresh grainy malt in aroma, remembering that this is one season later. Lots of lace layers and dots down my glass. A flavorful bitter, and the can lists but 4%. Satisfying this warm summer day, creamy mouthfeel, and drying finish.
draft at hopleaf, chicago- a lot of esters here, but also has a nice clean smoothness accompanied by the slightest of toasty notes that would have me go back to this one again.
Clear amber with large white head. Sweet aroma with hoppy and caramel notes. Sweet flavor with floral hops and fruity notes. Ends bitter.

Pours a lightly hazy, glowing orange amber.  A pillowy, cream colored head settles slowly to a thin film, leaving random gobs of patchy lacing on the glass.  The nose is heavy on piney hops and orange marmalade, with a toasty caramel malt backbone and drying grains.  Flavors include resinous pine hops, bitter orange, sweet, toasty pale malts, and dry grassiness.  The finish is bone dry, with lingering bitterness, which makes you want more and more.  Slightly less than medium bodied and moderately carbonated, I could sit and drink this all day long.  Excellent summertime session beer.
This is like a hop soda.  A lot of hop, but little to stand it up.  DOn’t get me wrong.  i liked it.  However this version of a bitter is best for hot summer days.

16 oz can from hellomynameis, Thanks a ton! Nose is very floral hops with an sweet apricot note; copper with a medium beige head; Flavor is hop bitterness with some lemony fruitiness and caramel malt; finish is lightly fruity and bitter.

Thanks to Rogueone for sharing a can. The beer pours a lustrous orange-gold color with a medium white head that dissipates steadily. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus and earthy malt. Light-bodied with sweet citrus and peach flavors along with touches of malt and piney hops. The finish is fruity and malty and lingers. Proof positive that it is possible to make a flavorful and easy to drink low-ABV beer.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2008 Big old can shared by footbalm. Pours a clear orange color with a medium white head. The aroma is light hops. The taste was pretty nice; some crisp hops, a touch of orange marmalade, and some toasty malt flavors. Quite simple, but nice. Enjoyable.
apricot, resin on nose. bitter on palate with some pineapple resiny stickyness. finishes a liitle disjointed but thats the only problem i find with this beer. very quaffable

(big thanks to irishboy for the free can)orange body with an awesome foamy white head.the aroma is just as described in the commercial description.peach,orange,and apricot aroma.all from the hops im guessing.the flavor has the same traits sitting in the back with some biscuits and caramel malts taking the front seat.this is an awesome bitter and i can see why it gets the high rating.

Can courtesy of theisti. Pours a hazy, pale copper with a pitted off-white head. The nose is fruity and floral with notes of dried apricots, lemon iced tea and grassy wildflowers. Fairly light bodied and slick with a moderately dry and bitter finish. Very quaffable. Light caramel malt sits behind a  blend of fruity, floral and herbal hops. This is definitely not your typical ESB, as the hops dominate the flavor profile, but it remains eminently drinkable and pretty darn tasty. Thanks again for the can, Tim!

7-13-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to pepsican 
Medium amber orange with a thin white head and some light lacing.  Smell is big hops and dough.  Flavor is hoppy but not fruity or floral or too terribly refreshing.  Medium to high carbonation.  Drinkable and hoppy just not very crisp or springy like I hoped.  Big honey flavors linger.

16oz can from theisti, thanks! Aroma is fruity as hell, with the peach really sticking out. The aroma also has some nice slighty roasty and toasty malt notes. I also pick up a bit of iced tea. Copper colored with a smallish off white head. The flavor is peach-a-plenty with a little earthiness, faint dark caramel, whole wheat crackers, and some other lighter fruits. This is different than any beer I have ever tried with the unique hop profile and I must say I am digging it. The finish is bitter, but not overly so. The mouthfeel is amazing for such a small beer. I must admit, this is the nice grain bill of a premium bitter, but with a distinctly non-English hop profile, but also not really a typical American hop profile. It is hard to remember  that this is a 4.2% beer. Thanks for this Frankenbeer Surly, another winner!

Can in trade from pepsican.  Thanks for this cool extra!

Pours a nice mostly clear golden color with a creamy medium lived beige head.  Smell is fresh mildly floral hops and oaty, nutty, creamy malt.  Taste is hoppier than most of the style, but is pleasantly balanced by honey like, oat cereal like malt and a crisp bitterness with pleasant lightly floral hop flavor.  This is very refreshing and sessionable.  Really nice overall!

16oz can, what a solid brew out of a can.  My 1st go at any of the Surly beers and it did not disapoint.  Some metalic "can" flavor hidden in the finish of the brew maybe?  Or was I just saying that as I stair at the can?  Poured into tulip glass.  Some sour / bitter flavors, intense and with terrific mouth feel, almost like it was barrel aged.  Cirtrus, hops, balanced flavor.  Really enjoyed this, and the price and packaging!

16oz can from Badbeer. Pours amber with a moderate sized, fizzy white head, good lace. Smells very earthy hoppy with some spices like basil and rosemary along with some iced tea. Tastes earthy hoppy and malty bitter, again with the spices and iced tea. Medium body, good carbonation. It’s good, I was expecting something different.

Can from iowaherkeye. Pours a nice orange/gold with a thin dissipating head. Aroma is that of nice floral and piney hops with a touch of citrus and some malty sweetness. Floral and herbal hops hit initially and are backed up by some toasted and lightly fruity malts. Some hops in the finish leave a light bitter effect lingering on the tongue. Seemed pretty light, had nice carbonation, and was a pleasure to drink. It proves that beers don’t have to be aged in a bourbon barrell and be 14% in order to be good. I would drink this everyday.

can from iowaherkeye.  thanks joey! I love pouring beer from a can into a pint glass where the beer actually fills to the top of the glass like a real pint.  Love these surly cans. Pours a hazy and deep orange golden with a small whispy white lace.  Aroma is earthy and slightly sweet, with a strong malt presence and a dash of fruity hops. Flavor begins with nice bready malt and finishes slightly sweet and bitter with notes of the citrus and peach.  Nice mouthfeel and a very delicious bitter overall.  Love these english style beers that are lower in alcohol but can still pack a mean flavor punch.  Could drink pints of this.  Well done.

Pours hazy golden with some brown hues.  Light fizzy off white head.  The aroma has is mostly a dusty malt character with dried apricot hop nose.  The flavor is spicy hops with a bit of grassy clippings.  Lots of dry malt character.  Medium body with a whole bunch of carbonation.  Dry bitter finish.  Easy to drink. Good.

Pours a golden yellow color with a quickly dissipating froth. Aroma is very earthy hops with some sweet malty notes. Flavor starts off very sweet and mellow but the hops come in quickly and take over through the finish. The bitterness is somewhat mild. Very strong pine and floral flavors. Medium bodied, this is a very refreshing esb that really isn’t too bitter, almost to the point of being an ipa.

Courtesy theisti. Wow, I like the hop aroma on this one with a big citric fruity peachy nose. Dark bread shores up the back end. Hazy copper with a nice but small foamy head. Oh man, starts with a one-two punch of herbal tobacco leaf hops and earthy biscuity malts, all propped up with a big soft pillowy mouthfeel, with light airy carbonation. Crisp balanced finish, with a lingering tingle of spicy hop. Theres alot of hop complexity in this, and a nice malt backbone for being low alcohol. Altogether quite nice.

Thanks to tytoanderso for the can. Clear orange color with a medium head. Aroma of caramel malts, biscuit and fresh grapefruit and pine hops. Dry and bitter taste. Crisp and good for a hot summer day..

Can from TomDecapolis.  Pours a mostly clear copper with a thin white head.  Aroma is toasted malts, slightly nutty, nice hearbal and floral hops with a touch of mint.  More herbal and tea-like hops in the flavor with fresh doughy yet crisp malts, and a clean bitter finish.  Pretty good for a bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2009 16 oz can brought down to KC from my Dad, via the assistance of tytoanderso at Zipps in Minneapolis, MN.  Pour is hazy orange copper with a one inch tan head. Carbonation bubbles rise to the top.  Very active looking beer.  Nice lacing. Aroma of very fresh pine hops and floral. Really clean and fresh smelling. Taste reveals some nice smooth caramel biscuit maltiness that transitions into the fresh hoppiness towards the end. Finish has some nice mild burnt toast flavor.  Palate is thin, clean and bordering on watery. Super nice session beer.

Can from Mrthirstyneck - thanks, Shane! Ooh baby, this is the stuff after a vigorous workout. Pours darker than expected, with liveliness that impresses coming out of a can (Surly continues to impress). Vigorous palate suits the crisp nose and the super dry flavors of the beer. There is definitely some tea in there, complement the hops and spice, a hint of pine. Very enjoyable.
had a great fruity aroma. Starts kind of bitter ends with some fruitiness, very easy to drink , wont kill your palate. perfect summer beer.

The beer was amber-orange with some off-white head that quickly dissipated. It was very fragrant with hints of floral, ice tea, and grapefruit hops. The flavor was similar with the addition of apricots and new vinyl (in a good way). Bitter ice tea hop finish. Very little hop burn compared to a Furious.

Poured a lightly hazy golden color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of toasted dough, toffee malts, citrus fruits, and a floral, grassy, hoppiness.  Taste of tropical fruits, more bread, a bit of toffee, faint caramel, with citrus fruits, light pine, and a nice bitterness in the finish.

(Can)  Pours a hazy amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of canned fruit cocktail, pineapple, grass, and biscuit.  Flavor of grapefruit, earthiness, toasted malt, and biscuit with a dry, moderately bitter finish.

16 oz can.  Pours a golden/orange color with a white head that settles down to a slight ring with nice lacing.  Nose is fruity and sweet with a bit of mango scent to it.  Starts like it will be very bitter but that gives way to a wave of citrus flavor.  Almost like a big breakfast beer.  :)  Imagine a two part beer, first part: ESB and second part: orange drink.  if that makes sense.  Leaves a slight aftertaste that lingers on the top of the tongue and back of the throat.  Very clean beer thats easy to drink.  Another success.

Poured from a 16oz can and served in an English pint glass.  This beer poured a slightly hazy golden amber with a thin head of tight, beige bubbles.  A small amount of spotty lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of pine, oranges, light caramel, and some bready malt.  The flavor included a crisp citric bitterness with a faint amount of bread dough.  The mouthfeel was light to medium-bodied with moderate carbonaton.  A decent session beer, but I guess I was hoping for more.
Pours a nice copperish orange.The nose has is peachy, & a bit tart.  Comes across the palate very clean with apricot, & citrus fruits. Finishes with a subtle hop taste that lingers.

A tart and peachy aroma with a slightly bitter, hoppy note. Body is a stunningly cloudy orange with a frothy white head.
Overall flavor, while predominantly hops and malt is quite light and refreshing - iced tea, cinnamon, and oatmeal- ending with a brief and amusing note of ginger.
Obviously a great sipping beer, I think it would be particularly well-suited with vinegary Kansas City-style BBQ.

Can. Pours a gorgeous orange-hued copper with a fair off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, with a strong hoppy scent of apricot and citrus along with a bit of maltiness.  Body is fairly light but malty, with a soft fruity flavor of apricot, citrus, and floral notes giving way to a tart, crisp finish not unlike strong tea.  As refreshing as a good bitter should be, but a bit more complex as well.

pours a nice orange copper with a medium off white head.
Aroma is toasty malt, a little oatmeal, plenty of orange citrus hop.
Flavour is light fruity/ orange hop with a medium malt body and a soft mouthfeel that fits with the traditional bitter style.
I can also get the black tea bitterness in the finish.
Very nice.
this is a great beer.  tastes very much like a dry hopped english bitter.  interesting characteristic.  surly makes the best beers ive ever had out of a can.

On tap at the Hop Leaf in Chicago. The aroma was fall leaves with some caramel. There was also a definite black tea note. The taste was bitter with some black tea. There was also some apple core along with a woody finish. This was ok, but I wanted a little more malt balance.

Can.  Pours absolutely gorgeous, stunning orange color with a nice soapy bright white head.  Perfect appearance.  There are a couple granules of something floating around in there.  I dont think its yeast but its interesting anyways.  Wonderful soft citrus hop aroma.  Soft is the word that keeps coming to my head.  Very nice smell of mango and some peach with a definite toasty maltiness underneath.  I can usually tell what kind of hops are used but this is confusing me.  Amarillo maybe? (Note: This review was written before I read the description and found out it is Glacier).  Taste is super smooth with a perfect level of carbonation.  Almost a cask ale type mouthfeel.  Very nice balance between the citrus hops and the toasted malt character.  Super drinkable.  This beer is phenominal.  What I would give to have constant access to this.

RateBeer is amazingly consistent for most beers for me.  I try this beer, made from a famous brewer like Surly.  I think it is mediocre (for the beers I try), but I expect that when I see the actual rating it will much higher than my rating, because of the fame of the brewer.  But, that is not the case.  Everyone seems to think this beer is the same quality as I think, despite the connection to a great beer such as Darkness.  Smells like oranges.  Orange color.  Mild bitternes.  Leans dry.  Nice

Courtesy TheCheeseMan.  Dark golden straw color, thin even white head.  Light toasty aroma touched by a mild earthy hop presence.  Smooth taste - nice grassy hops over a healthy malt base.  A good bitter.

Can (love it!) courtesy of Guerde.  Pours a clear amber with one finger off-white head and nice lacing.  Nose is mild floral and bitter hops with some bready malts. Taste is mild malt with some citrus before a nice dry bitter finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Good beer  thanks Andy!

Can.  Dark orange pour with no head.  Aroma of marmalade, citrusy and herbal hops.  Similar flavor with a slight sourness.  Also, just a hint of smokiness in the finish.  Malty and carbonated mouthfeel.  Very nice, interesting beer.
DFW Tasting 6/8/08 Thanks to Bu11zeye for sharing!  Aroma is grassy and citrus. The flavor falls short of this but this is a great session beer!  Cheers!

Smells of hops, citrus, grass, much like open a bag of fresh hops.  Looks is light amber with a decent head.  Pineapple, fruits, pine, and others citus in the taste with a nice light bitterness that goes down easy.

Pours like a hazy iced tea with a decent off-white head that shows good retention and lacing.  Smells a little like iced tea too with leafy hops and some spices on top of the malt background.  Definitely some citrus and pine hops with lots of grassy scents in there.  Taste also has pine and citrus hops, mainly grass and leaves.  Definitely get oranges, grapefruits and lemon zest in the taste.  The hops were a bit tart and balanced out well with the sweetness of the caramel malts.  Mouthfeel is medium and very (you guessed it) bitter with strong carbonation.  This is definitely a drinkable brew despite the bitter connotations and taste.  Its like a nice iced tea on a summer afternoon.

Sweet bonus from OSLO, thanks again buddy. Pours clear deep gold with white head. It as a full aroma of crystal malts, floral perfume, sweet sugary strawberries and a bit of orange juice. The taste is much the same as the nose with floral hop bitterness then some crystal malt sweetness moving into sweet citrus hop notes. Nice brew that doesnt seem to be a bitter due to its bold flavors that dont burst the boundaries of the style by too much.

Thanks to puzzl for the can.  Pale amber beer with a thick white head.  Aroma is a little bit woody and lightly fruity.  A bit of diacetyl.  Some soft caramel sweetness, but the beer itself is quite thin-bodied.  As it warms some nice apricot fruitiness and light earthy hoppiness comes to the fore.  Lightly honeyish as well.  Unusual flavour on the back that reminds me of sandalwood and cologne.  This is a strange brew.

Thanks to joey for shairng.  Pours amber with a small white head.  Aroma is up from fruit and a bit of hops.  Flavor is mainly tea,  some fruit an a bit of hop citrus comes through as well.  Finishes watery.

Goldish copper color with a white head with great retention and lacing.  Aroma of tangerine, apricots, and some perfume notes.  Taste is immediately of apricots, followed by some sort of sweet candy that Im not sure of the name of, followed by some tangerine in the finish.  Light bodied and on the lower side of medium carbonation.

Can from Hellomynameis. Oh man, this smells so good.  Absolutely fragrant, lush perfume, huge notes of dried apricots and grapefruit. A wonder for the nose. If I met a girl with perfume that smelled like this Id marry her on the spot. A white, fluffy cloud of a head sits atop the russet body. The flavor, on the other hand, is a bit of a miss, very floral but lightly acid, astringent, with a rough, watery finish. Amazing the difference.

On tap at McKenzies in Minneapolis.  Pours a lightly hazy amber/copper with golden notes and a medium bubbly/creamy off white head that laced.  Aroma of orange, iced tea, caramel, apricot, really nice hoppy nose.  Flavor is a nice smooth apricot/citrus, caramel, tea, bready.  Hop bitterness very low, hop flavor is in your face.  Great beer!  Not your typical ESB.  Interesting move with using oats in this beer.  But it works, really smooths this beer out.
Smells and tastes of blueberry.  Dry, with a surprising sparkling fruit water flavor.  Bitter hops with dry hops aftertaste.
Pours a fairly clear amber with minimal white head. Aroma is a sweetened pint lime, hops. Flavor is light pint and hops. Body is right.

Can from Tytoanderson.  Shared with my girlfriend Cyn.  Nice orange pour with a tan head.  Really nice hoppy nose, with some light bitterness.  A very much hoppy bitter and overall I have to say I like it.  Its a really nice balance and creates a really nice drinkable sessionable beer.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2009 [Can] Pours a deep gold with a moderate, soapy, off white head. Dry hop is immediately noticeable on the nose with lots of citrus. Also present are the toast and apricot marmalade. Flavor is well balanced, plenty of malt, not overly sweet, with a sharp, lasting bitterness. There is that nice toasty character present as well. Overall, I really liked this one.

can thanks to incutrav..... pours a semi-transparent orange brown with a thin soapy slightly off-white head.... aroma was very grassy with some additonal orangey-citrus and light malt notes.... flavors had some orange zest, grassy hops, and a little malt.  medium carbonation with an average mouthfeel.

Sampled this one while in Minneapolis. 16 oz can. Pours out a a dark amber with an light orange head on top. Aroma is gentle but nice with a bit of sweetness of citrus and apricots meeting the nose. Taste is very hoppy at first with oranges, caramel, and biscuit-like malts meeting the mouth. The taste also has another slight fruity flavor that I cant quite figure out. It tastes almost like that syrup you get in canned peaches. Oh well, the flavor is very subtle and doesnt take away from the beer. The finish ends well as this fairly sweet beer snaps shut with  a bitter but not overpowering end. Very nice.

16oz can acquired in trade with tytoanderso (thanks!). Poured a medium orange color, lightly hazy, and an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of floralness, pine, citrus, toasted malts, and bready. Nice hoppiness in the aromas. Tastes of toasted malts, some caramel, lightly floral, and bread. At 4%, this would make a great session beer.

Decent little bittah heah! Nice floral hops in this one as well. Pours golden to amber with some fluffy head. Nice thin mouthfeel, with a bitter end. Flavor has orange peel, bready yeast and the bitter note.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 1st Can courtesy of Ibrew2or3, 2nd can courtesy tpd975. Pours a clear golden with a one finger mostly lasting white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of citrus marmalade goodness and floral hops with notes of bready and nutty malt. Taste is the same as aroma.  Medium mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness. Very good

16oz Can. Thanks for bringing this back Jake! Orange rind, whole wheat toast, and light goat barn blend with a sweet figure of very grassy, yet lightly resin-filled hops. Bright and filled with a fresh summer breeze. Pours a clearish, brown-tinted orange with a tall soapy white head. Flavor is a little flaccid and oily. The malts come as crystal and filtered. Theres a tangy orange rind sensation, but then a woody blast of grainy hops. A bit biting, but the grassiness of the hops comes across as refreshing and light. The malt is a bit goaty and animal-like, but it holds up well to the hops. This is hoppy and bitter, with good hop flavors, but maybe a little too bitter, for bitterness sake. Anyway, it leaves a long sweetgrass, grapefruit rind, and bergamot soak on the tongue. Interesting. Initially, Im a little perplexed and let down by some of the malt flavors, but they clean up a little and the tremendous hoppiness just shines in a basking fruit and grass glow that only Surly can pull off. And for that, this is a good beer.

(16oz can, thanks ryan) Medium beige head atop clear amber body.  Aroma is intensely bitter, medium sweet, grapefruit, pine, some biscuit.  Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, biscuit/bread.  Soft, watery light body.

Can from tytoanderso. Clear light amber body with a medium white head. Massive amounts of herbal and floral hops along with plenty of bready, biscuity malts. The flavor is very lightly sweet, light to moderate bitterness, spicy herbal hops, flowers, dough and caramel. Medium/light body is round with moderate carbonation. Delicious.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2010 Rerate: 16oz can, courtesy of MatSciGuy. Thanks, Levi! Pours a slightly hazy, deep, tarnished orange color; fizzy, light-tan head with large bubbles; solid retention and light lacing. The aroma is quite earthy overall, with a malt character somewhere between Marris Otter-like and a very light crystal malt, with the core note being soft tea; gently aromatic hop character: earthy, citrus, and floral notes, but non-astringent and not roughly bitter at all; just a touch watery, or seemingly watery, as this is so softly presented. Medium-light body; medium (or less) carbonation; non-astringent; slightly more bitterness than the aroma suggests: earthy, citrus, and floral (again); very soft, rounded hop character; overall, nothing biting or astringent. The malt core is very quiet: tea-like, lightly earthy, again Marris Otter-like but not quite; just a touch of wateriness in the presentation; this is a passable rendition, and a very nice, rounded hop character, but very quiet and (again) a touch watery. Medium finish of soft earthy bitterness and lightly toasty British malts; nicely dry. 7.3.7.3.14=3.4

1 pint can, courtesy of ryan.  Thanks!  Pours a hazy orange color; off-white head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Earthy, biscuity malts and hop bitterness; clear, crisp nose.  Medium mouthfeel: touch of wateriness at the edges, but crisp earthy and biscuity hops and chewy, doughy maltiness; decent and quite drinkable stuff, but lacking in body and a touch messy.  Decent hop character.  Medium finish: dry bready notes and a bit of earthy bitterness at the far end. 7.4.7.3.12=3.3

Can from Zac. Light orange color with hugh off white head. Floral aroma with lite tea and caramel biscuits. The taste was the same with nice bitter finish.Thinner body, but thats ok. Great session brew. I could pound the shit out of these.

biscuits, honey, marmalade and oats in the nose, along with a hint of hop bitterness. The flavor is kind of strange - the hop bitterness hits the tongue immediately, but then the flavor (in its entirety, malts, hops, everything) is gone a second later. This makes the beer very drinkable, and very refreshing, but also kind of a tease. Decent enough, but not Surlys best effort.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 16oz can.  Thanks Guerde.  Very interesting beer here.  Yeah, its all kinds of bitter but it vanishes as soon as you taste it, which is good. Plenty of fresh tasting varietal hops in here.  Warrior, eh?  I might have to give them a shake.  Nice session ale, though the bitterness would not make it an all day affair.  Another good ale from Surly.

16 oz can. Orange color, mildly fizzy, small head. Flavor is mild malt, finishes dry and hoppy. Lots of citric and pine hop presence in this one. Palate is smooth. Crisp and clean finish. Good amount of flavor for a beer with such a low ABV. Another solid Surly brew.

Bottle courtesy of tytoanderso:  Wow.  What an interesting beer!   Prominently biscuity aroma of honey, some pine, and apricots.  Drinks completely opposite of aroma, with bitterness up front, fading to sweet malt, then a dryness and finish of iced tea.  Confusing, but tasty.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: On cask at Maproom. Amber pour with medium sudsy head. Aroma is american hops, citrusy grapefruit forward. I agree with 17th floor in the aroma not carrying over so much to the flavor. Flavor is much more english. Herbal and floral hop flavors, a somewhat grassy bitterness, and just a hint of the citrus detected in the nose. Hop driven for sure. Very smooth session beer. Glad to have tried this on cask.

[on cask at Maproom]  Pours a faint amber with a medium sudsy white froth.  Faint grapefruit / peach fresh hop aroma.  The aroma doesnt carry much into the flavor.  Flavor is very distant but balanced.  Lightly bitter, resiny and peachy.  A very mellow brew.  Not extremely malty, nor hoppy, but still manages that English cheeriness.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2009 on cask at the maproom. pours hazy light amber with soapy white head. aroma of grapefruit, pine, and slightly chemical. flavors is refreshing, grapefruit, citrus, pine, not much malt profile here, watery, medium bitterness coming in on the backend. pretty nice PNW ESB. 3.3. 

11/2/09, thanks to bang for this one. pours hazy golden-amber with white head. nose of mild pine, orange citrus, and mildly toasted malts. a lot of perceived bitterness with hop notes of peach and apricot, with a sturdy malt backbone. a crisp and refreshing brew. 3.4.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2012 [Can, thanks Guerde] Pours dark amber with a decent khaki head. Aroma is not a surprise, as it is big on fresh hops. The description is pretty accurate, with the most noticeable aromas being apricot (strongest) and peach. There are also a good amount of malt in the background. The taste is much more malt dominant   Good mouthfeel, smooth and with a lightly citrusy and fairly dry, bitter finish. The taste is somewhat weak, but I wasnt expecting a flavor bomb with this beer anyways. Pretty solid and definitely would be a good session beer. Ill revisit this rating when I have had more bitters to compare it to. Re-rate: Just taking it down a tenth of a point. More tea in the taste, but less hoppy than I remembered it overall. Still smells great. Old rating: 8/3/7/4/14 = 3.6Re-rate: Aroma is huge on lemon iced tea, with a little playdough present as well. Lots of tea in the taste--this beer seems to get more tea dominant each time I have it. Mild bitterness in the taste, with lots of lemon iced tea again, and some peach. I remember this as being better. The taste has grown on me, but the aroma is a little worse than I remember. Overall, this isnt a bad beer by any means, but Im slightly less impressed each time I have it.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 (can) Pours amber with a white head that settles to a fine film with decent lacing.  Aroma is strong with fruit. The noted orange and apricot are the most evident, but also a hint of pine, and an underlying earthiness that occurs near the end of the sniff which intensifies as the beer warms.  A really pleasant smell here.  Sadly, the taste did not live up to the aroma.  The flavor begins with just a very light sweetness, that is almost immediately replaced by a clean and dry lemon/grapefruit rind finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  I havent had many bitters, but this one would definitely be a decent session beer.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 This was genius.  An absolute highlight of Dark Lord 08.  Unbelievable squeezed orange juice flavor in an ESB  Are you even kidding me?  It barely even tastes like an ESB, but in a good way  Surly does it again.
Poured a cloudy orange color with hardly any white head.  Aroma of was hoppy and fruity. Taste was also kind of fruity and sour. Decent beer, but did not taste like the style.

On tap at Dark Lord Day 08.  I thought this beer was decent and it helped to have a break from the Darklord.  Pours a hazy orange.  Fruity hoppy aroma.  It almost tasted like tea, which was interesting.  Not as bold as their other beers but still good.
On tap at Dark Lord Day 08.  Poured a hazy amber color.  Has very little aroma to it.  Tasted like a weak IPA.  Has more water taste to it than anything else.  Was not an impressive beer at all.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 Cask, DLD 2008. Tasted like a hop tee. Not a ton of hop bitterness, though had a nose of glaciers. Very fruity and light. Nice.

Tap at Kumas, 6/27/8. Very nice beer with some oaty caramel tastes. Pour is copper with a fluffy head. Compared to the cask version, this has a lot more going on. I suspect the cask we had was still green. This is a damn fine sessionable beer.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2009 Cask. Arborfest 2008. Expressive aroma of apricot and tangerine. Bright, beautiful and delicate. Lighter malt notes hide behind the hops. Pours hazy orange. Flavor is heavy on the malted barley and toasted bread notes. Bread crust and dough with apricots on the finish. Creamy with good carbonation. Decent bitter finish. 

Out of the can its a fantastic Summer Session. Crisp, vibrant and tasty as hell.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2008 Tap at the Nile.  Clear orange amber with large head and good lace.  The aroma is grassy, piney, orange, and faint malt.  The flavor is of clean tasting malt with some sweetness, orange marmalade, and hops.  All very mild and bready/fruity.  The palate is light and refreshing.  Good, but pretty mild and middle of the road for these guys.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2008 Draft at Stub & Herb’s.  Yellow-amber body with smooth, white head.  Fresh, green hop aroma along with grass and yeast.  Aroma gets slightly skunky as it warms.  Light bodied and drinkable.  Flavor is pretty much green, bitter hops that come off a little astringent along with a faint hint of citrus.  Clean, crisp, bitter finish.  The hop flavors overpower most of the characteristics of an ESB that you expect.

On tap at Happy Gnome.  I expectd more than this from Surly.  Golden orange in color with a white head that dissipates quickly.  Sweet malt on the nose with a touch of citrus.  The flavor is almost bland for Surly.  The citrus comes through more in the taste as the malt gives way to it refusingly.  This may be good as a session beer.

tap at hop leaf chicago, not what I expected, kinda faint taste. not all that.  Lacks taste and aroma, was easy to drink but left me wanting more. glad to get this out of my head but not impressed. thanks but i will pass next time. overrated!

Draft @ Blue Nile, Minneapolis: Hazy gold, nice white head and great lacing. Nose of sweet toast biscuity malt and spicy herbal hops, plenty of citrus too. The flavor is nice with an intense dry hop note along with a soft, almost cask-like mouthfeel. Balanced, moderate body. Nice and zesty, very little bitterness. Tasty! Supper hoppy yet the impact of a golden ale.

Had this on tap at the gnome back in Mar/April.......yes I am that far behind.  Pours a nice cloudy orangish golden, with a nice white head.  Very citrusy nose with very little in the way of floral hops.  Nice creamy mouthfeel with tropical fuits and citrus.  Very nice!
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: RBSG 2007 Pub Crawl  Cask at the Happy Gnome. Muddy yellowish golden brown with no head. Big fresh grapefruit and orange nose. Mildly soft mouthfeel, a tad on the thin side. Far milder flavor than the nose implied, muted grapefruit and pineapple flavors, light astringency in the finish. Nice!

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2008 From cask. Pours hazy orange with no head. Aroma is distinctly grapefruit. No carbonation. Fruity flavour, grapefruit. Reminds me most of a grapefruit juice than a beer. Finish has some peach notes and a mild bitterness as well. Had this gone bad? I dont think it was meant to taste so dull.6-2-6-3-11=2.8

50 cL can, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours hazy orange with a diminished white head. Dense hoppy and bitter aroma with a solid peachy/citrusy aroma. Bitter and solid fruity flavoured with a mild peachy note. Bitter and fruity finish. Quite crisp and nicely hopped.7-3-8-3-15=3.6

On cask at The Happy Gnome during the RBSG 2007 Pub Crawl. Cloudy orange-amber body with no head. Very sweet huge grapefruit aroma. Very gentle grapefruit flavor with some light lemon in the ending. Excellent easy drinker.

Well, I see from the ratings being all over the board here that some love it, hate it, or are somewhere in the middle.  I would be in that middle group.  There is a honey, apricot, and grapefruit scent to this bitter.  The taste is bitter, yet not overly so.  A clean finish.  Slightly watered down, but what can I expect when this was followed by two 10%+ monsters previously.  Still, this would be a nice session beer any day of the week.  Even though this beer is one of my lower rated Surly beers, my total score tells you it is still a winner.
A lot peach comes through in the aroma. Strong bitterness, too strong for the amount of sweetness. Good for a bitter, but this isnt my favorite style of beer to begin with.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2008 On cask.  Actually a bad beer from surly.  Completely cloudy, and very sour.  The sourness is not from infection but grapefruit flavor.  Lightly bitter with some fruit.  3/3/2/1/5
-------Ta from a can May, 2008.  Much better.  Fairly dry and very drinkable but loaded with hops.  The only thing ESB about it is the name, as it is much too intense to fit in that style.  Good palate now and some fruity hops.  Score raised considerably.

On Tap at Old Chicago in Uptown.  I really like all of the other Surly brews Ive had, and I really wanted to try this one-off since Im not in Minneapolis all that often.  I really wanted to like it, because I really like this brewery... But there was just no way.  It had OK head retention and it was cloudy, which I dont mind at all.  It was very low carbonation.. Under 2.5 volumes, Id say, which is appropriate for this style.. But it was sour and dry - it tasted infected actually.    I could sense vague hints of wonderful hops and those awesome british heirloom 2-row malts behind everything, but some wild yeast or bacteria strain had found its way in and ruined it.  I bet this tasted awesome when it was fresh.. The kegs too old, not stored properly, or theres contamination issues going on.  I pounded it anyways, cuz I dont like to waste craft beer.. and then happily ordered a Furious.  Aint the first time Ive had craft beer that had turned, and sadly it probably wont be the last.  Just a reminder that proper sanitation, storage, transport and cellaring are really so important.  Keep dialing it in Surly, Ill always try your brews when Im in Minneapolis.

Yellow/orange/red, this falls somewhere in there. Lots of hoppy aromas, with a lot of grapefruit and citrus like aromas. The taste is initially and quickly fruity - grapefruity. Then there is a sharp bitterness and and lots of grapefruit taste that finishes out to a very drinkable  light beer. This is quite good and very drinkable..
On tap at Old Chicagos Uptown. Wasnt the best bitter or Surly for that matter, but decent.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2007 Two pint glasses on tap at Macs Industrial Sports Bar in Nordeast Minneapolis. Wonderful, hoppy, sweetly fruity and remarkably floral aroma features apricot, grapefruit, and peach scents (by the way, I wrote that before reading the commercial description). Pours a hazy, sparkling brass with a small amount of off-white head. Very appetizing appearance. The flavor is dominated by good, solid, adventurous American hops. The taste matches the smell, with a heavy pitted fruit presence. Bitter brewer is very hoppy and far from well-balanced. Take away the hops, and this is a forgettable beer. But why would you ever take away the hops? Theyre awesome! Bitter hops aftertaste. Medium body. Stunning crispness that I have experienced before only in the best lagers and never in another ale.

Surly has done it again! This is my kind of beer! It has less malty goodness than Furious but even better hops. I have scored all four Surly beers that I have tried well into the fours. Honestly, I was hoping that I would not have liked this beer and would have been forced to have given it a bad review, because I do not want to come across as a homer. But, like Bender, Furious, and Darkness, it is just so damn good that I cant help but give it another rave. I just cant help but love this beer. I do echo badgerben in saying that, despite the name, I would classify this as an American pale ale rather than any variety of bitter.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 Original Rating May 25, 2007:</>  Hazy, light copper color with a thin head.  Aroma of apricots and hops.  Tastes like... like an APA with slightly past ripe apricots dumped in. Copper color with a medium head.  Light grain aroma, along with a mix of earthy English and floral hops.  Orange taste, very earthy and a vegetal bitterness.  The apricot is there just at the tip of the tongue before the bitterness crushes it.  Better this time around.
On tap at Old Chicago Uptown in Minneapolis with scluffman and Skyview.  Massive citrus peel wafts from this hazy yellow beer.  Dry hopped body with orange peel and a nice bitter hop finish.

Lightly hazed apricot marmalade appearance...no kiddin...under a crisp, creamy white head...really, crisp and creamy...this is so far, one of the paler Surlys yet (maybe Cynic was lighter?), but the least alcoholic, for sure. (4.2%)

orange/ apricot marmalade dominates the aroma, also...fresh with citric zest...pithy, zippy...and a little sticky...

Taste: big bitter blast, tangy and tart, then nothing but refreshment. Easy drinking ale, this, crisp, snappy, light bodied, but full of testure, flavor and character. Bitter lemon rind feel keeps creeping into the palate.Then it fades back, with the hoppy kick still hanging on.

Interesting. Very much like a smooth, light ESB, but with that special something you get from the hops we grow on this continent. I am liking this, a great late spring sessioner.

Once again, an utterly unique, new creation from Surly. Keep em coming , guys!

Tap at the Muddy Pig.  Clear, flowery blonde color.  Crisp hops dominate the nose - mandarin and orange and a punch of pineapple.  Tastes distinctively British with its honey biscuit and grass body.  Highlighted with accents of little lilac flower hops and some papery crystal notes.  Trace of toffee hard candy on the smack.  Palate approaches aggression cautiously and never quite arrives.  Obviously, an interesting sessioner.

Sampled on tap the day after the unveiling at the Old Chicago Uptown in Minneapolis, MN. Shared beer with brewfiend and scluffman. Pours a hazy pale golden brew with a thick white head that dissoved to a fine film on top. Excellent lacing. Aroma has scents of pine hops, orange peel, and some pitted fruit. Taste is lightly carbonated, smooth with the hop bitterness that makes this a true Premium Bitter. The finish is smooth and dry with a small hop bite, but not as over the top like Surly Furious. I can not call this beer as Furious Light because I consider "Light Beers" as diet beers. Surly Bitter Brewer is most appropriate name. According to Omar, only one batch was made. I hope to see this beer available again after the beer runs out.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2010 On tap a Old Chicago Uptown.  The commercial description pretty much hits it on the head.  Peach really came through for me on this one. Nice bitter bite at the end. The peach taste is not for me, but if you like peach and a bitter kick in the end, this is the beer for you. A little lighter on the pallete then the bender but not thin.

On tap at the official unveiling at OC Uptown. Great balanced beer.  It was explained to me that Omar and the rest of Surly have been asked why they dont make a light beer, well they told me this is their answer.  How great is that.  Nice Hop aroma with some fruity notes.  Good malt finish with a balanced hop flavor.  I am first and foremost a Furious man, but I could sit back with a few of these and be happy.

Had quite a few samples of this at Arborfest 07. This is an "American Style Bitter", but no category for that.  Great flavor for a 4.2 abv  brew with low IBUs. Good hop bite up front, not much hop burn left on the pallet. I thought this was like a lighter version of Furious. Very drinkable, probably more session-able then Furious. I havent drank many of this style, so im no expert. Probably the easiest drinking Surly Brew to date. Thats not saying  that I wont drink 5 Furious in an evening though too. Hoppin Mad won the vote for the name, but Omar found out that it was already taken, so Bitter Brewer took the prize. Good stuff!
